   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">North Korea</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. For the Republic of Korea, see <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Korea_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Korea (disambiguation)">Korea (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in East Asia
      </div> 
      <p><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=North_Korea&amp;params=40_N_127_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">40°N</span> <span class="longitude">127°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">40°N 127°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">40; 127</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

      <p><b>North Korea</b> (<a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>: <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0" class="extiw" title="wikt:조선">조선</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9C%9D%E9%AE%AE" class="extiw" title="wikt:朝鮮">朝鮮</a>, <a href="/wiki/McCune%E2%80%93Reischauer" title="McCune–Reischauer">MR</a>: <i>Chosŏn</i>; literally <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%B6%81%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0" class="extiw" title="wikt:북조선">북조선</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8C%97%E6%9C%9D%E9%AE%AE" class="extiw" title="wikt:北朝鮮">北朝鮮</a>, <a href="/wiki/McCune%E2%80%93Reischauer" title="McCune–Reischauer">MR</a>: <i>Pukchosŏn</i>, or <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EB%B6%81%ED%95%9C" class="extiw" title="wikt:북한">북한</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8C%97%E9%9F%93" class="extiw" title="wikt:北韓">北韓</a>, <a href="/wiki/Revised_Romanization_of_Korean" title="Revised Romanization of Korean">RR</a>: <i>Bukhan</i> in South Korean usage), officially the <b>Democratic People's Republic of Korea</b> (<b>DPRK</b> or <b>DPR Korea</b>; Korean: <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0%EB%AF%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%9D%98%EC%9D%B8%EB%AF%BC%EA%B3%B5%ED%99%94%EA%B5%AD" class="extiw" title="wikt:조선민주주의인민공화국">조선민주주의인민공화국</a>/<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9C%9D%E9%AE%AE%E6%B0%91%E4%B8%BB%E4%B8%BB%E7%BE%A9%E4%BA%BA%E6%B0%91%E5%85%B1%E5%92%8C%E5%9C%8B" class="extiw" title="wikt:朝鮮民主主義人民共和國">朝鮮民主主義人民共和國</a>, <i>Chosŏn Minjujuŭi Inmin Konghwaguk</i>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> constituting the northern part of the <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korean Peninsula</a>. The country is bordered to the north <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93North_Korea_border" title="China–North Korea border">by China</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93Russia_border" title="North Korea–Russia border">by Russia</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Amnok" class="mw-redirect" title="Amnok">Amnok</a> (known as the Yalu in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Tumen_River" title="Tumen River">Tumen</a> rivers, and to the south by <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, with the heavily fortified <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">Korean Demilitarized Zone</a> (DMZ) separating the two. North Korea, like its southern counterpart, claims to be the legitimate government of the entire peninsula and adjacent islands. <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a> is the country's capital and largest city. </p>
      <p>In 1910, <a href="/wiki/Korean_Empire" title="Korean Empire">Korea</a> was <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">annexed</a> by <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperial Japan">Imperial Japan</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">Japanese surrender</a> at the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia" title="End of World War II in Asia">end of World War II</a> in 1945, Korea was <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">divided into two zones</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Civil_Administration" title="Soviet Civil Administration">north occupied by the Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Military_Government_in_Korea" title="United States Army Military Government in Korea">south occupied by the United States</a>. Negotiations on <a href="/wiki/Korean_reunification" title="Korean reunification">reunification</a> failed, and in 1948, separate governments were formed: the socialist Democratic People's Republic of Korea in the north, and the capitalist <a href="/wiki/First_Republic_of_Korea" title="First Republic of Korea">Republic of Korea</a> in the south. <a href="/wiki/Operation_Pokpoong" title="Operation Pokpoong">An invasion</a> initiated by North Korea led to the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> (1950–1953). The <a href="/wiki/Korean_Armistice_Agreement" title="Korean Armistice Agreement">Korean Armistice Agreement</a> brought about a ceasefire, but no peace treaty was signed. </p>
      <p>According to article 1 of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_North_Korea" title="Constitution of North Korea">constitution of North Korea</a>, the DPRK is an "independent <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist State</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-ccc_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccc-20">[n 3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-naenara_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naenara-21">[18]</a></sup> North Korea <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_North_Korea" title="Elections in North Korea">holds elections</a>, though they have been described by independent observers as <a href="/wiki/Sham_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Sham election">sham elections</a>. North Korea is a <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">totalitarian</a><sup id="cite_ref-:9_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:9-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:10_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:10-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-britannica_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-6">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nysuccess_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nysuccess-25">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup> with an elaborate <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_cult_of_personality" title="North Korean cult of personality">cult of personality</a> around the <a href="/wiki/Kim_dynasty_(North_Korea)" title="Kim dynasty (North Korea)">Kim dynasty</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Workers' Party of Korea">Workers' Party of Korea</a> (WPK), led by a member of the ruling family, holds absolute power in the state and leads the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Front_for_the_Reunification_of_the_Fatherland" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Front for the Reunification of the Fatherland">Democratic Front for the Reunification of the Fatherland</a> of which all political officers are required to be members. According to article 3 of the constitution of the DPRK, <i><a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">Juche</a></i> is the North Korean official ideology.<sup id="cite_ref-naenara_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naenara-21">[18]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Means_of_production" title="Means of production">means of production</a> are owned by the state through <a href="/wiki/State-run_enterprise" class="mw-redirect" title="State-run enterprise">state-run enterprises</a> and <a href="/wiki/Collective_farming" title="Collective farming">collectivized farms</a>. Most services—such as healthcare, education, housing and food production—are subsidized or state-funded. From 1994 to 1998, North Korea suffered <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_famine" title="North Korean famine">a famine</a> that resulted in the deaths of between 240,000 and 420,000 people, and the population continues to suffer malnutrition. North Korea follows <i><a href="/wiki/Songun" title="Songun">Songun</a></i>, or "military-first" policy. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by number of troops">country with the highest number of military and paramilitary personnel</a>, with a total of 9,495,000 active, reserve and paramilitary personnel, or approximately <span data-sort-value="7001371630026046587♠" style="display:none"></span>37% of its population. Its active duty army of 1.21 million is the fourth-largest in the world, after China, the United States and India; consisting of <span data-sort-value="7000473588553466425♠" style="display:none"></span>4.7% of its population. It <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="North Korea and weapons of mass destruction">possesses nuclear weapons</a>. In addition to being a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> since 1991, North Korea is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G77</a> and the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Regional_Forum" class="mw-redirect" title="ASEAN Regional Forum">ASEAN Regional Forum</a>. </p>
      <p>A 2014 UN inquiry into abuses of <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_North_Korea" title="Human rights in North Korea">human rights in North Korea</a> concluded that, "the gravity, scale and nature of these violations reveal a state that does not have any parallel in the contemporary world," with <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> holding similar views.<sup id="cite_ref-Amnesty_International_2007_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amnesty_International_2007-27">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ohchr.org_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohchr.org-28">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hrw1_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw1-29">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hrw2_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw2-30">[27]</a></sup> The North Korean government denies these abuses.<sup id="cite_ref-human_rights4_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-human_rights4-31">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor-32">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kcna.co.jp_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kcna.co.jp-33">[30]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">
       <input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none">
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Names">Names</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Korea" title="Names of Korea">Names of Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The name <i>Korea</i> derives from the name <i>Goryeo</i> (also spelled <i>Koryŏ</i>). The name <i>Goryeo</i> itself was first used by the ancient kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a> (Koguryŏ) which was one of the great powers in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> during its time,<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[34]</a></sup> ruling most of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a>, parts of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup> under <a href="/wiki/Gwanggaeto_the_Great" title="Gwanggaeto the Great">Gwanggaeto the Great</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup> The 10th-century kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a> succeeded Goguryeo,<sup id="cite_ref-Koryo1_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo1-41">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Koryo2_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo2-42">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Koryo3_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo3-43">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Koryo4_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo4-44">[41]</a></sup> and thus inherited its name, which was pronounced by visiting Persian merchants as "Korea".<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup> The modern spelling of Korea first appeared in the late 17th century in the travel writings of the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Hendrick_Hamel" title="Hendrick Hamel">Hendrick Hamel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UDN_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UDN-46">[43]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the division of the country into North and South Korea, the two sides used different terms to refer to Korea: <i>Chosun</i> or <i>Joseon</i> (조선) in North Korea, and <i>Hanguk</i> (한국) in South Korea. In 1948, North Korea adopted <i>Democratic People's Republic of Korea</i> (<a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>: <span lang="ko">조선민주주의인민공화국</span>, <i>Chosŏn Minjujuŭi Inmin Konghwaguk</i>; <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ko-%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0%EB%AF%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%9D%98%EC%9D%B8%EB%AF%BC%EA%B3%B5%ED%99%94%EA%B5%AD.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Ko-%EC%A1%B0%EC%84%A0%EB%AF%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%A3%BC%EC%9D%98%EC%9D%B8%EB%AF%BC%EA%B3%B5%ED%99%94%EA%B5%AD.oga" class="internal" title="Ko-조선민주주의인민공화국.oga">listen</a></span></span>) as its new legal name. In the wider world, because the government controls the northern part of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, it is commonly called North Korea to distinguish it from South Korea, which is officially called the <i>Republic of Korea</i> in English. Both governments consider themselves to be the legitimate government of the whole of <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[45]</a></sup> For this reason, the people do not consider themselves as 'North Koreans' but as Koreans in the same divided country as their compatriots in the South and foreign visitors are discouraged from using the former term.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[46]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_North_Korea" title="History of North Korea">History of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Founding">Founding</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg/160px-Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="216" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg/240px-Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg/320px-Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg 2x" data-file-width="439" data-file-height="594"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kim_Il-sung_in_1950.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>, the founder of North Korea
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a>, Korea was <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">occupied by Japan</a> from 1910 to 1945. Korean resistance groups known as <a href="/wiki/Dongnipgun" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongnipgun">Dongnipgun</a> (Liberation Army) operated along the Sino-Korean border, fighting guerrilla warfare against Japanese forces. Some of them took part in allied action in China and parts of <a href="/wiki/South_East_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="South East Asia">South East Asia</a>. One of the guerrilla leaders was the communist <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>, who later became the first leader of North Korea. </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">Japanese surrender</a> at the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia" title="End of World War II in Asia">end of World War II</a> in 1945, <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">the Korean Peninsula was divided</a> into two zones along the <a href="/wiki/38th_parallel_north" title="38th parallel north">38th parallel</a>, with the northern half of the peninsula occupied by the Soviet Union and the southern half <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Military_Government_in_Korea" title="United States Army Military Government in Korea">by the United States</a>. Negotiations on <a href="/wiki/Korean_reunification" title="Korean reunification">reunification</a> failed. Soviet general <a href="/wiki/Terentii_Shtykov" class="mw-redirect" title="Terentii Shtykov">Terentii Shtykov</a> recommended the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Civil_Authority" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Civil Authority">Soviet Civil Authority</a> in October 1945, and supported <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a> as chairman of the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_People%27s_Committee_for_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Provisional People's Committee for North Korea">Provisional People's Committee for North Korea</a>, established in February 1946. In September 1946, South Korean citizens rose up against the Allied Military Government. In April 1948, an <a href="/wiki/Jeju_Uprising" class="mw-redirect" title="Jeju Uprising">uprising of the Jeju islanders</a> was violently crushed. The South declared its statehood in May 1948 and two months later the ardent anti-communist <a href="/wiki/Syngman_Rhee" title="Syngman Rhee">Syngman Rhee</a><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[47]</a></sup> became its ruler. The Democratic People's Republic of Korea was established in the North on 9 September 1948. Shtykov served as the first Soviet ambassador, while Kim Il-sung became premier. </p>
      <p>Soviet forces withdrew from the North in 1948, and most American forces withdrew from the South in 1949. Ambassador Shtykov suspected Rhee was planning to invade the North and was sympathetic to Kim's goal of Korean unification under socialism. The two successfully lobbied <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> to support a quick war against the South, which culminated in the outbreak of the Korean War.<sup id="cite_ref-LankovArticle_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LankovArticle-51">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABC-CLIO_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABC-CLIO-52">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lankov1945-1948_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lankov1945-1948-53">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lankov2_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lankov2-54">[51]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Korean_War">Korean War</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Aftermath_of_the_Korean_War" title="Aftermath of the Korean War">Aftermath of the Korean War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">Korean Demilitarized Zone</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="North Korea–South Korea relations">North Korea–South Korea relations</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Korean_war_1950-1953.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Korean_war_1950-1953.gif/170px-Korean_war_1950-1953.gif" decoding="async" width="170" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Korean_war_1950-1953.gif/255px-Korean_war_1950-1953.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Korean_war_1950-1953.gif/340px-Korean_war_1950-1953.gif 2x" data-file-width="562" data-file-height="871"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Korean_war_1950-1953.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Territory often changed hands early in the war, until the front stabilized.
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#EF767E; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;North Korean, Chinese, and Soviet forces
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#73AA73; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;South Korean, U.S., Commonwealth, and United Nations forces
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Military_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Military of North Korea">military of North Korea</a> invaded the <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South</a> on 25 June 1950, and swiftly overran most of the country. A <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Command" title="United Nations Command">United Nations force</a>, led by the United States, intervened to defend the South, and rapidly advanced into North Korea. As they neared the border with China, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Volunteer_Army" title="People's Volunteer Army">Chinese forces</a> intervened on behalf of North Korea, shifting the balance of the war again. Fighting ended on 27 July 1953, with <a href="/wiki/Korean_Armistice_Agreement" title="Korean Armistice Agreement">an armistice</a> that approximately restored the original boundaries between North and South Korea, but no peace treaty was signed.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> Approximately 3 million people died in the Korean War, with a higher proportional civilian death toll than <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, making it perhaps the deadliest conflict of the Cold War-era.<sup id="cite_ref-Kim_p.45_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kim_p.45-56">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cumings_p._35_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cumings_p._35-57">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lewy_pp._450-453_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewy_pp._450-453-60">[57]</a></sup> In both per capita and absolute terms, North Korea was the country most devastated by the war, which resulted in the death of an estimated 12–15% of the North Korean population (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 10 million), "a figure close to or surpassing the proportion of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">Soviet citizens killed in World War II</a>," according to <a href="/wiki/Charles_K._Armstrong" title="Charles K. Armstrong">Charles K. Armstrong</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup> As a result of the war, almost every substantial building in North Korea was destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[60]</a></sup> Some have referred to the conflict as a civil war, with other factors involved.<sup id="cite_ref-AMH_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AMH-64">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A heavily guarded <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">demilitarized zone</a> (DMZ) still divides the peninsula, and an anti-communist and anti-North Korea sentiment remains in South Korea. Since the war, the United States has maintained a strong <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forces_Korea" title="United States Forces Korea">military presence in the South</a> which is depicted by the North Korean government as an imperialist occupation force.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup> It claims that the Korean War was caused by the United States and South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-Brune1996_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brune1996-66">[63]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-war_developments">Post-war developments</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg/230px-Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg/345px-Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg/460px-Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="400"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dprk_pyongyang_tchholima_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Chollima_Statue" title="Chollima Statue">Statue</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chollima_Movement" title="Chollima Movement">Chollima Movement</a> in Pyongyang
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The relative peace between the South and the North following the armistice was interrupted by border skirmishes, celebrity abductions, and assassination attempts. The North failed in several assassination attempts on South Korean leaders, such as <a href="/wiki/Blue_House_Raid" class="mw-redirect" title="Blue House Raid">in 1968</a>, 1974, and the <a href="/wiki/Rangoon_bombing" title="Rangoon bombing">Rangoon bombing</a> in 1983; tunnels were found under the DMZ and tensions flared over the <a href="/wiki/Axe_murder_incident" class="mw-redirect" title="Axe murder incident">axe murder incident</a> at <a href="/wiki/Panmunjom" title="Panmunjom">Panmunjom</a> in 1976.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[64]</a></sup> For almost two decades after the war, the two states did not seek to negotiate with one another. In 1971, secret, high-level contacts began to be conducted culminating in the 1972 <a href="/wiki/July_4th_North%E2%80%93South_Joint_Statement" class="mw-redirect" title="July 4th North–South Joint Statement">July 4th North–South Joint Statement</a> that established principles of working toward peaceful reunification. The talks ultimately failed because in 1973, South Korea declared its preference that the two Koreas should seek separate memberships in international organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[65]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 1956 <a href="/wiki/August_Faction_Incident" title="August Faction Incident">August Faction Incident</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a> successfully resisted efforts by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and China to depose him in favor of <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Koreans_faction" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Koreans faction">Soviet Koreans</a> or the pro-Chinese <a href="/wiki/Yan%27an_faction" title="Yan'an faction">Yan'an faction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sino-SovietSplit_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sino-SovietSplit-69">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NKMajorPowers_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKMajorPowers-70">[67]</a></sup> The last Chinese troops withdrew from the country in October 1958, which is the consensus as the latest date when North Korea became effectively independent. Some scholars believe that the 1956 August incident demonstrated independence.<sup id="cite_ref-Sino-SovietSplit_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sino-SovietSplit-69">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NKMajorPowers_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKMajorPowers-70">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009XV_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009XV-71">[68]</a></sup> North Korea remained closely aligned with China and the Soviet Union, and the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_split" title="Sino-Soviet split">Sino-Soviet split</a> allowed Kim to play the powers off each other.<sup id="cite_ref-Armstrong2_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Armstrong2-72">[69]</a></sup> North Korea sought to become a leader of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and emphasized the ideology of <i><a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">Juche</a></i> to distinguish it from both the Soviet Union and China.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup> In United States policymaking, North Korea was considered among the <a href="/wiki/Captive_Nations" title="Captive Nations">Captive Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg/230px-Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg/345px-Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg/460px-Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3578" data-file-height="2385"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pyongyang_metro_station_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_Metro" title="Pyongyang Metro">Pyongyang Metro</a> with bomb shelters functions
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Recovery from the war was quick—by 1957 industrial production reached 1949 levels. In 1959, relations with Japan had improved somewhat, and North Korea began allowing the repatriation of Japanese citizens in the country. The same year, North Korea revalued the <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_won" title="North Korean won">North Korean won</a>, which held greater value than its South Korean counterpart. Until the 1960s, economic growth was higher than in South Korea, and North Korean GDP per capita was equal to that of its southern neighbor as late as 1976.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009XXXII,_46_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009XXXII,_46-75">[72]</a></sup> However, by the 1980s, the economy had begun to stagnate; it started its long decline in 1987 and almost completely collapsed after the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991, when all Soviet aid was suddenly halted.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrench200797–99_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrench200797–99-76">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>An internal CIA study acknowledged various achievements of the North Korean government post-war. Compassionate care for war orphans and children in general, a radical improvement in the status of women, free housing, free healthcare, health statistics particularly in life expectancy and infant mortality that were comparable to even the most advanced nations up until the <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_famine" title="North Korean famine">North Korean famine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup> Life expectancy in the North was 72 before the famine which was only marginally lower than in the South.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-78">[75]</a></sup> The country once boasted a comparatively developed healthcare system; pre-famine North Korea had a network of nearly 45,000 family practitioners with some 800 hospitals and 1,000 clinics.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post_Cold_War">Post Cold War</span></h3> 
      <p>In 1992, as Kim Il-sung's health began deteriorating, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> slowly began taking over various state tasks. Kim Il-sung <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Kim_Il-sung" title="Death and state funeral of Kim Il-sung">died of a heart attack in 1994</a>, with Kim Jong-il declaring a three-year period of national mourning before officially announcing his position as the new leader afterwards.<sup id="cite_ref-edit_CNN-_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edit_CNN--80">[77]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea promised to halt its development of nuclear weapons under the <a href="/wiki/Agreed_Framework" title="Agreed Framework">Agreed Framework</a>, negotiated with U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> and signed in 1994. Building on <a href="/wiki/Nordpolitik" title="Nordpolitik">Nordpolitik</a>, South Korea began to engage with the North as part of its <a href="/wiki/Sunshine_Policy" title="Sunshine Policy">Sunshine Policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kim Jong-il instituted a policy called <i><a href="/wiki/Songun" title="Songun">Songun</a></i>, or "military first". There is much speculation about this policy being used as a strategy to strengthen the military while discouraging coup attempts.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[80]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Flooding in the mid-1990s exacerbated the economic crisis, severely damaging crops and infrastructure and led to <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_famine" title="North Korean famine">widespread famine</a> which the government proved incapable of curtailing, resulting in the deaths of between 240,000 and 420,000 people. In 1996, the government accepted UN food aid.<sup id="cite_ref-Spoorenberg_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spoorenberg-84">[81]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/2017-18_North_Korea_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2017-18 North Korea crisis">2017-18 North Korea crisis</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018-19_Korean_peace_process" class="mw-redirect" title="2018-19 Korean peace process">2018-19 Korean peace process</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg/230px-2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg/345px-2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg/460px-2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2012_new_residential_buildings_at_intersection_Sungni_St-Mansudae_St_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Apartment buildings in Pyongyang
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The international environment changed with the election of U.S. president <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> in 2001. His administration rejected South Korea's Sunshine Policy and the Agreed Framework. The U.S. government treated North Korea as a <a href="/wiki/Rogue_state" title="Rogue state">rogue state</a>, while North Korea redoubled its efforts to acquire nuclear weapons to avoid the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">fate of Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[84]</a></sup> On 9 October 2006, North Korea announced it had conducted <a href="/wiki/2006_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2006 North Korean nuclear test">its first nuclear weapons test</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-radioactive_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-radioactive-88">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nukeconfirmed_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nukeconfirmed-89">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/U.S._President" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. President">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> adopted a policy of "strategic patience", resisting making deals with North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> Tensions with South Korea and the United States increased in 2010 with the <a href="/wiki/ROKS_Cheonan_sinking" title="ROKS Cheonan sinking">sinking of the South Korean warship <i>Cheonan</i></a><sup id="cite_ref-Anger_at_North_Korea_over_sinking_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anger_at_North_Korea_over_sinking-91">[88]</a></sup> and North Korea's <a href="/wiki/Bombardment_of_Yeonpyeong" title="Bombardment of Yeonpyeong">shelling of Yeonpyeong Island</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 17 December 2011, Kim Jong-il <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Kim_Jong-il" title="Death and state funeral of Kim Jong-il">died from a heart attack</a>. His youngest son <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> was announced as his successor.<sup id="cite_ref-apdeath_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-apdeath-94">[91]</a></sup> In the face of international condemnation, North Korea continued to develop its nuclear arsenal, possibly including a <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_bomb" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydrogen bomb">hydrogen bomb</a> and a missile capable of reaching the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-95">[92]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Throughout 2017, following <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>'s assumption of the US presidency, tensions between the United States and North Korea increased, and there was heightened rhetoric between the two, with Trump threatening "fire and fury"<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[93]</a></sup> and North Korea threatening to test missiles that would land near <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[94]</a></sup> The tensions substantially decreased in 2018, and a détente developed.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-98">[95]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9320_Korean_peace_process" title="2018–20 Korean peace process">series of summits</a> took place between Kim Jong-un of North Korea, President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> of South Korea, and President Trump.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[96]</a></sup> It has been 3&nbsp;years, 2&nbsp;months since North Korea's last ICBM test. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_North_Korea" title="Geography of North Korea">Geography of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_Topography.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/North_Korea_Topography.png/220px-North_Korea_Topography.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/North_Korea_Topography.png/330px-North_Korea_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/North_Korea_Topography.png/440px-North_Korea_Topography.png 2x" data-file-width="1705" data-file-height="1753"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_Topography.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map of North Korea
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea occupies the northern portion of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, lying between latitudes <a href="/wiki/37th_parallel_north" title="37th parallel north">37°</a> and <a href="/wiki/43rd_parallel_north" title="43rd parallel north">43°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/124th_meridian_east" title="124th meridian east">124°</a> and <a href="/wiki/131st_meridian_east" title="131st meridian east">131°E</a>. It covers an area of 120,540 square kilometers (46,541&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-unstats08_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unstats08-9">[7]</a></sup> North Korea is <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93North_Korea_border" title="China–North Korea border">bordered by China</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93Russia_border" title="North Korea–Russia border">by Russia</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Amnok" class="mw-redirect" title="Amnok">Amnok</a> (known as the Yalu in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Tumen_River" title="Tumen River">Tumen</a> rivers<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[97]</a></sup> and borders South Korea along the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">Korean Demilitarized Zone</a>. To its west are the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korea_Bay" title="Korea Bay">Korea Bay</a>, and to its east lies Japan across the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_(22961925095).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg/220px-0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg/330px-0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg/440px-0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_%2822961925095%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:0409_-_Nordkorea_2015_-_Kumgang_Gebirge_(22961925095).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Kumgang" title="Mount Kumgang">Mount Kumgang</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_(14876597009).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg/220px-North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg/330px-North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg/440px-North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_%2814876597009%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2786" data-file-height="1568"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_coast_near_Hamhung_(14876597009).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korean coast near <a href="/wiki/Hamhung" title="Hamhung">Hamhung</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Early European visitors to Korea remarked that the country resembled "a sea in a heavy gale" because of the many successive <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">mountain ranges</a> that crisscross the peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-Topography_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Topography-101">[98]</a></sup> Some 80 percent of North Korea is composed of mountains and uplands, separated by deep and narrow valleys. All of the Korean Peninsula's mountains with elevations of 2,000 meters (6,600&nbsp;ft) or more are located in North Korea. The highest point in North Korea is <a href="/wiki/Paektu_Mountain" title="Paektu Mountain">Paektu Mountain</a>, a volcanic mountain with an elevation of 2,744 meters (9,003&nbsp;ft) above sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-Topography_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Topography-101">[98]</a></sup> Considered a sacred place by North Koreans, Mount Paektu holds significance in Korean culture and has been incorporated in the elaborate folklore and cult personality around the Kim dynasty.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[99]</a></sup> For example, the song, "We Will Go To Mount Paektu" sings in praise of Kim Jong-un and describes a symbolic trek to the mountain. Other prominent ranges are the <a href="/wiki/Hamgyong_Mountains" title="Hamgyong Mountains">Hamgyong Range</a> in the extreme northeast and the <a href="/wiki/Rangrim_Mountains" title="Rangrim Mountains">Rangrim Mountains</a>, which are located in the north-central part of North Korea. <a href="/wiki/Mount_Kumgang" title="Mount Kumgang">Mount Kumgang</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Taebaek_Mountains" title="Taebaek Mountains">Taebaek Range</a>, which extends into South Korea, is famous for its scenic beauty.<sup id="cite_ref-Topography_101-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Topography-101">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The coastal plains are wide in the west and discontinuous in the east. A great majority of the population lives in the plains and lowlands. According to a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Environmental_Programme" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Environmental Programme">United Nations Environmental Programme</a> report in 2003, forest covers over 70 percent of the country, mostly on steep slopes.<sup id="cite_ref-United_Nations_Environmental_Programme_12_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_Nations_Environmental_Programme_12-103">[100]</a></sup> North Korea had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 8.02/10, ranking it 28<sup>th</sup> globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-104">[101]</a></sup> The longest river is the <a href="/wiki/Amnok" class="mw-redirect" title="Amnok">Amnok</a> (Yalu) River which flows for 790 kilometers (491&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[102]</a></sup> The country contains three terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Central_Korean_deciduous_forests" title="Central Korean deciduous forests">Central Korean deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Changbai_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Changbai Mountains mixed forests">Changbai Mountains mixed forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Manchurian_mixed_forests" title="Manchurian mixed forests">Manchurian mixed forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-106">[103]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg/200px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg/300px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg/400px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1378" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PRK_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korea map of Köppen climate classification
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea experiences a combination of <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-United_Nations_Environmental_Programme_12_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_Nations_Environmental_Programme_12-103">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-climate_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-107">[104]</a></sup> but most of the country experiences a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> within the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> scheme. Winters bring clear weather interspersed with snow storms as a result of northern and northwestern winds that blow from <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-107">[104]</a></sup> Summer tends to be by far the hottest, most humid, and rainiest time of year because of the southern and southeastern <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> winds that carry moist air from the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>. Approximately 60 percent of all precipitation occurs from June to September.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-107">[104]</a></sup> Spring and autumn are transitional seasons between summer and winter. The daily average high and low temperatures for <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a> are −3 and −13&nbsp;°C (27 and 9&nbsp;°F) in January and 29 and 20&nbsp;°C (84 and 68&nbsp;°F) in August.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_107-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-107">[104]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>

           <span style="font-size:110%;">Largest cities or towns in North Korea</span>
           <br>
           <div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;">
            <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20100331091148/http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/sources/census/2010_PHC/North_Korea/Final%20national%20census%20report.pdf">2008 Census</a>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg" class="image" title="Pyongyang"><img alt="Pyongyang" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg/120px-Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg/180px-Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg/240px-Pyongyang_western_view_April_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3587" data-file-height="2690"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg" class="image" title="Hamhung"><img alt="Hamhung" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg/120px-Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="80" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg/180px-Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg/240px-Hamhung_North_Korea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="427"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Hamhung" title="Hamhung">Hamhung</a> </td>
