      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_North_Korea" title="Government of North Korea">Government of North Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_North_Korea" title="Politics of North Korea">Politics of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG/220px-Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG/330px-Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG/440px-Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3267" data-file-height="2420"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae-Kongressalle.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mansudae_Assembly_Hall" title="Mansudae Assembly Hall">Mansudae Assembly Hall</a>, seat of the Supreme People's Assembly
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea functions as a highly centralized, <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a>. According to its <a href="/wiki/2016_Constitution_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Constitution of North Korea">2016 constitution</a>, it is a self-described revolutionary and <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a> "guided in its activities by the Juche idea and the Songun idea".<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[105]</a></sup> In addition to the constitution, North Korea is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Ten_Principles_for_the_Establishment_of_a_Monolithic_Ideological_System" title="Ten Principles for the Establishment of a Monolithic Ideological System">Ten Principles for the Establishment of a Monolithic Ideological System</a> (also known as the "Ten Principles of the One-Ideology System") which establishes standards for governance and a guide for the behaviors of North Koreans.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[106]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Workers' Party of Korea">Workers' Party of Korea</a> (WPK), led by a member of the Kim dynasty,<sup id="cite_ref-scmp-yoo-sep-18-2013_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scmp-yoo-sep-18-2013-110">[107]</a></sup> has an estimated 3,000,000 members and dominates every aspect of North Korean politics. It has two satellite organizations, the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Social_Democratic_Party" title="Korean Social Democratic Party">Korean Social Democratic Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chondoist_Chongu_Party" title="Chondoist Chongu Party">Chondoist Chongu Party</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009192_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009192-111">[108]</a></sup> which participate in the WPK-led <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Front_for_the_Reunification_of_the_Fatherland" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Front for the Reunification of the Fatherland">Democratic Front for the Reunification of the Fatherland</a> of which all political officers are required to be members.<sup id="cite_ref-parlunion5_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-parlunion5-112">[109]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kim_dynasty_(North_Korea)" title="Kim dynasty (North Korea)">Kim dynasty</a> is the current Supreme Leader or <i>Suryeong</i> of North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-leon_DPRK_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leon_DPRK-113">[110]</a></sup> He heads all major governing structures: he is <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea">General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea</a>, Chairman of the <a href="/wiki/State_Affairs_Commission_of_North_Korea" title="State Affairs Commission of North Korea">State Affairs Commission of North Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Korean_People%27s_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Commander of the Korean People's Army">Supreme Commander of the Korean People's Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NK_Leaders_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NK_Leaders-114">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[112]</a></sup> His grandfather <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>, the founder and leader of North Korea until his death in 1994, is the country's "<a href="/wiki/Eternal_President" class="mw-redirect" title="Eternal President">eternal President</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-hitchens07_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hitchens07-116">[113]</a></sup> while his father <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> who succeeded Kim Il-sung as the leader was announced "Eternal General Secretary" and "Eternal Chairman of the National Defence Commission" after his death in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-NK_Leaders_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NK_Leaders-114">[111]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_North_Korea" title="Constitution of North Korea">Constitution of North Korea</a>, there are officially three main branches of government. The first of these is the <a href="/wiki/State_Affairs_Commission_of_North_Korea" title="State Affairs Commission of North Korea">State Affairs Commission of North Korea</a>, which acts as "the supreme national guidance organ of state sovereignty".<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[115]</a></sup> Its role is to deliberate and decide the work on defense building of the State, including major policies of the State; and to carry out the directions of the Chairman of the commission, Kim Jong-Un. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Legislative_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative power">Legislative power</a> is held by the unicameral <a href="/wiki/Supreme_People%27s_Assembly" title="Supreme People's Assembly">Supreme People's Assembly</a> (SPA). Its 687 members are elected every five years by <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[116]</a></sup> though the elections have been described by outside observers as <a href="/wiki/Sham_election" class="mw-redirect" title="Sham election">sham elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-defectorcensus_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-defectorcensus-121">[118]</a></sup> Supreme People's Assembly sessions are convened by the SPA Presidium, whose president (<a href="/wiki/Choe_Ryong-hae" title="Choe Ryong-hae">Choe Ryong-hae</a> since 2019) represents the state in relations with foreign countries. Deputies formally elect the President, the vice-presidents and members of the Presidium and take part in the constitutionally appointed activities of the legislature: pass laws, establish domestic and foreign policies, appoint members of the cabinet, review and approve the state economic plan, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009198_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009198-122">[119]</a></sup> The SPA itself cannot initiate any legislation independently of party or state organs. It is unknown whether it has ever criticized or amended bills placed before it, and the elections are based around a single list of WPK-approved candidates who stand without opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009197–198_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009197–198-123">[120]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Executive_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive power">Executive power</a> is vested in the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_North_Korea" title="Cabinet of North Korea">Cabinet of North Korea</a>, which has been headed by <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_North_Korea" title="Premier of North Korea">Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Kim_Dok-hun" class="mw-redirect" title="Kim Dok-hun">Kim Dok-hun</a> since 14 August 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[121]</a></sup> The Premier represents the government and functions independently. His authority extends over two vice-premiers, 30 <a href="/wiki/Minister_(government)" title="Minister (government)">ministers</a>, two cabinet commission chairmen, the cabinet chief secretary, the president of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" title="Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Central Bank</a>, the director of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bureau_of_Statistics_(North_Korea)" title="Central Bureau of Statistics (North Korea)">Central Bureau of Statistics</a> and the president of the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Sciences_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" title="Academy of Sciences of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Academy of Sciences</a>. A 31st ministry, the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_People%27s_Armed_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of People's Armed Forces">Ministry of People's Armed Forces</a>, is under the jurisdiction of the State Affairs Commission.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009200_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009200-125">[122]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea, like its southern counterpart, claims to be the legitimate government of the entire <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean peninsula</a> and adjacent islands.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[123]</a></sup> Despite its official title as the "Democratic People's Republic of Korea", some observers have described North Korea's political system as an <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[126]</a></sup> or a "hereditary dictatorship".<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[127]</a></sup> It has also been described as a <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinist</a> <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_ideology">Political ideology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">Juche</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">Juche</a></i> ideology is the cornerstone of party works and government operations. It is viewed by the official North Korean line as an embodiment of Kim Il-sung's wisdom, an expression of his leadership, and an idea which provides "a complete answer to any question that arises in the struggle for national liberation".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009203_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009203-131">[128]</a></sup> <i>Juche</i> was pronounced in December 1955 in a speech called <i><a href="/wiki/On_Eliminating_Dogmatism_and_Formalism_and_Establishing_Juche_in_Ideological_Work" title="On Eliminating Dogmatism and Formalism and Establishing Juche in Ideological Work">On Eliminating Dogmatism and Formalism and Establishing Juche in Ideological Work</a></i> in order to emphasize a Korea-centered revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009203_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009203-131">[128]</a></sup> Its core tenets are <a href="/wiki/Economic_self-sufficiency" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic self-sufficiency">economic self-sufficiency</a>, military self-reliance and an independent foreign policy. The roots of <i>Juche</i> were made up of a complex mixture of factors, including the cult of personality centered on Kim Il-sung, the conflict with pro-Soviet and pro-Chinese dissenters, and Korea's centuries-long struggle for independence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009204_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009204-132">[129]</a></sup> <i>Juche</i> was introduced into <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_North_Korea" title="Constitution of North Korea">the constitution</a> in 1972.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartin2004111_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartin2004111-134">[131]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><i>Juche</i> was initially promoted as a "creative application" of <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a>, but in the mid-1970s, it was described by state propaganda as "the only scientific thought... and most effective revolutionary theoretical structure that leads to the future of communist society". <i>Juche</i> eventually replaced Marxism–Leninism entirely by the 1980s,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009206_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009206-135">[132]</a></sup> and in 1992 references to the latter were omitted from the constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009186_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009186-136">[133]</a></sup> The 2009 constitution dropped references to communism and elevated the <i><a href="/wiki/Songun" title="Songun">Songun</a></i> military-first policy while explicitly confirming the position of Kim Jong-il.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[134]</a></sup> However, the constitution retains references to socialism.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[135]</a></sup> <i>Juche</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s concepts of self-reliance have evolved with time and circumstances, but still provide the groundwork for the spartan austerity, sacrifice and discipline demanded by the party.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009207_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009207-139">[136]</a></sup> Scholar <a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Brian Reynolds Myers</a> views North Korea's actual ideology as a <a href="/wiki/Korean_ethnic_nationalism" title="Korean ethnic nationalism">Korean ethnic nationalism</a> similar to <a href="/wiki/Statism_in_Sh%C5%8Dwa_Japan" title="Statism in Shōwa Japan">statism in Shōwa Japan</a> and European <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[139]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kim_dynasty">Kim dynasty</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kim_dynasty_(North_Korea)" title="Kim dynasty (North Korea)">Kim dynasty (North Korea)</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_cult_of_personality" title="North Korean cult of personality">North Korean cult of personality</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg/230px-Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg/345px-Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg/460px-Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4176" data-file-height="2951"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae-Monument-Bow-2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korean citizens paying respect to the statues of Kim Il-sung (left) and Kim Jong-il at the <a href="/wiki/Mansu_Hill_Grand_Monument" title="Mansu Hill Grand Monument">Mansudae Grand Monument</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea is ruled by the Kim dynasty, which in North Korea is referred to as the <i>Mount Paektu Bloodline</i>. It is a three-generation lineage descending from the country's first <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Leader of North Korea">leader</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>. Kim developed <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_cult_of_personality" title="North Korean cult of personality">a cult of personality</a> closely tied to the state philosophy of <i><a href="/wiki/Juche" title="Juche">Juche</a></i>, which was later passed on to his successors: his son <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> and grandson <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a>. In 2013, this lineage was made explicit when Clause 2 of Article 10 of the newly edited <i>Ten Fundamental Principles of the <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Workers' Party of Korea">Korean Workers' Party</a></i> stated that the party and revolution must be carried "eternally" by the "Mount Paektu Bloodline".<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[140]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <i>New Focus International</i>, the cult of personality, particularly surrounding Kim Il-sung, has been crucial for legitimizing the family's hereditary succession.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[141]</a></sup> The control the North Korean government exercises over many aspects of the nation's culture is used to perpetuate the <a href="/wiki/Cult_of_personality" title="Cult of personality">cult of personality</a> surrounding Kim Il-sung,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMyers2011100_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMyers2011100-145">[142]</a></sup> and Kim Jong-il.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMyers2011113_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMyers2011113-146">[143]</a></sup> While visiting North Korea in 1979, journalist Bradley Martin wrote that nearly all music, art, and sculpture that he observed glorified "Great Leader" Kim Il-sung, whose personality cult was then being extended to his son, "Dear Leader" Kim Jong-il.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartin2004353_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartin2004353-147">[144]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Claims that the dynasty has been deified are contested by North Korea researcher <a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">B. R. Myers</a>: "Divine powers have never been attributed to either of the two Kims. In fact, the propaganda apparatus in Pyongyang has generally been careful <i>not</i> to make claims that run directly counter to citizens' experience or common sense."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMyers20117_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMyers20117-148">[145]</a></sup> He further explains that the state propaganda painted Kim Jong-il as someone whose expertise lay in military matters and that the famine of the 1990s was partially caused by natural disasters out of Kim Jong-il's control.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMyers2011114,_116_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMyers2011114,_116-149">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg/220px-Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg/330px-Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg/440px-Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Chung_Eui-yong_and_Kim_Jong-un.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> and his sister <a href="/wiki/Kim_Yo-jong" title="Kim Yo-jong">Kim Yo-jong</a> (right) in March 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The song "<a href="/wiki/No_Motherland_Without_You" title="No Motherland Without You">No Motherland Without You</a>", sung by the North Korean army choir, was created especially for Kim Jong-il and is one of the most popular tunes in the country. Kim Il-sung is still officially revered as the nation's "<a href="/wiki/Eternal_President" class="mw-redirect" title="Eternal President">Eternal President</a>". Several landmarks in North Korea are <a href="/wiki/List_of_things_named_after_Kim_Il-sung" title="List of things named after Kim Il-sung">named for Kim Il-sung</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung_University" title="Kim Il-sung University">Kim Il-sung University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung_Stadium" title="Kim Il-sung Stadium">Kim Il-sung Stadium</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung_Square" title="Kim Il-sung Square">Kim Il-sung Square</a>. Defectors have been quoted as saying that North Korean schools deify both father and son.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[147]</a></sup> Kim Il-sung rejected the notion that he had created a cult around himself, and accused those who suggested this of "<a href="/wiki/Political_faction" title="Political faction">factionalism</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartin2004105_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartin2004105-151">[148]</a></sup> Following the death of Kim Il-sung, North Koreans were prostrating and weeping to a bronze statue of him in an organized event;<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[149]</a></sup> similar scenes were broadcast by state television following the death of Kim Jong-il.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Critics maintain that Kim Jong-il's personality cult was inherited from his father. Kim Jong-il was often the center of attention throughout ordinary life. His birthday is one of the most important <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_North_Korea" title="Public holidays in North Korea">public holidays in the country</a>. On his 60th birthday (based on his official date of birth), mass celebrations occurred throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[151]</a></sup> Kim Jong-il's personality cult, although significant, was not as extensive as his father's. One point of view is that Kim Jong-il's cult of personality was solely out of respect for Kim Il-sung or out of fear of punishment for failure to pay homage,<sup id="cite_ref-Hermit_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hermit-155">[152]</a></sup> while North Korean government sources consider it genuine hero worship.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[153]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The extent of the cult of personality surrounding Kim Jong-il and Kim Il-sung was illustrated on 11 June 2012 when a 14-year-old North Korean schoolgirl drowned while attempting to rescue portraits of the two from a flood.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[154]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>10 January 2021, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> was formally elected as the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea">General Secretary</a> in <a href="/wiki/8th_Congress_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="8th Congress of the Workers' Party of Korea">8th Congress</a> of the ruling <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Workers' Party of Korea">Workers' Party of Korea</a>, inheriting the title from his late father <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a>, who <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Kim_Jong-il" title="Death and state funeral of Kim Jong-il">died</a> in 2011. <sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[155]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_North_Korea" title="Foreign relations of North Korea">Foreign relations of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_-_China_friendship_(5578914865).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg/220px-North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg/330px-North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg/440px-North_Korea_-_China_friendship_%285578914865%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1280"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_-_China_friendship_(5578914865).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The close <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93North_Korea_relations" title="China–North Korea relations">China-North Korea relationship</a> is celebrated at the <a href="/wiki/Arirang_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Arirang Festival">Arirang Mass Games</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a result of its isolation, North Korea is sometimes known as the "<a href="/wiki/Hermit_kingdom" title="Hermit kingdom">hermit kingdom</a>", a term that originally referred to the isolationism in the latter part of the <a href="/wiki/Joseon_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Joseon Dynasty">Joseon Dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-alja_NKorLankov_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alja_NKorLankov-159">[156]</a></sup> Initially, North Korea had diplomatic ties only with other communist countries, and even today, most of the foreign embassies accredited to North Korea are located in <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a> rather than in <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[157]</a></sup> In the 1960s and 1970s, it pursued an independent foreign policy, established relations with many developing countries, and joined the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>. In the late 1980s and the 1990s its foreign policy was thrown into turmoil with the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_bloc" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet bloc">Soviet bloc</a>. Suffering an economic crisis, it closed a number of its embassies. At the same time, North Korea sought to build relations with developed free market countries.<sup id="cite_ref-DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations-161">[158]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea joined the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> in 1991 together with South Korea. North Korea is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G77</a> and the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Regional_Forum" class="mw-redirect" title="ASEAN Regional Forum">ASEAN Regional Forum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea enjoys a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93North_Korea_relations" title="China–North Korea relations">close relationship with China</a> which is often called North Korea's closest ally.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[161]</a></sup> The relations were strained in the last few years because of China's concerns about North Korea's nuclear program. However, the relations have started to improve again and been increasingly close especially after <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary of the Communist Party of China</a> visited North Korea in April 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[162]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=North_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, North Korea had diplomatic relations with 166 countries and embassies in 47 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DPRK_Diplomatic_Relations-161">[158]</a></sup> However, owing to the human rights and political situation, North Korea does not have diplomatic relations with <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Botswana" title="Botswana">Botswana</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-suspension_of_diplomatic_relations_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-suspension_of_diplomatic_relations-166">[163]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-France_and_Estonia_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-France_and_Estonia-167">[164]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[165]</a></sup> and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-ddd_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ddd-169">[n 4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Haggard_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haggard-170">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup> As of September 2017, France and Estonia are the last two European countries that do not have an official relationship with North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup> North Korea continues to have strong ties with its socialist southeast Asian allies in <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, as well as with <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_(2019-04-25)_05.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg/220px-Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg/330px-Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg/440px-Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_%282019-04-25%29_05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kim_Jong-un_and_Vladimir_Putin_(2019-04-25)_05.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korean leader Kim Jong-un meeting with Russian President <a href="/wiki/Putin" class="mw-redirect" title="Putin">Putin</a>, 25 April 2019
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg/220px-2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg/330px-2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg/440px-2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="636"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit_-_Kim_and_Trump_shake_hands.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> and North Korean Leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2018_North_Korea-United_States_summit" class="mw-redirect" title="2018 North Korea-United States summit">2018 North Korea-United States summit</a> in Singapore, June 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea was previously designated a <a href="/wiki/State_Sponsors_of_Terrorism" class="mw-redirect" title="State Sponsors of Terrorism">state sponsor of terrorism</a><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> because of its alleged involvement in the 1983 <a href="/wiki/Rangoon_bombing" title="Rangoon bombing">Rangoon bombing</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Air_Flight_858" title="Korean Air Flight 858">1987 bombing of a South Korean airliner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup> On 11 October 2008, the United States removed North Korea from its list of states that sponsor terrorism after Pyongyang agreed to cooperate on issues related to its nuclear program.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> North Korea was re-designated a state sponsor of terrorism by the U.S. under the <a href="/wiki/Trump_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Trump administration">Trump administration</a> on 20 November 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_abductions_of_Japanese_citizens" title="North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens">The kidnapping of at least 13 Japanese citizens</a> by North Korean agents in the 1970s and the 1980s has affected North Korea's relationship with Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> met with Kim in Singapore on 12 June 2018. An agreement was signed between the two countries endorsing the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Panmunjom_Declaration" title="Panmunjom Declaration">Panmunjom Declaration</a> signed by North and South Korea, pledging to work towards denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/2019_North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_Hanoi_Summit" title="2019 North Korea–United States Hanoi Summit">They met in Hanoi</a> from 27 to 28 February 2019, but failed to achieve an agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[176]</a></sup> On 30 June 2019, Trump met with Kim along with <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> at the Korean DMZ.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Inter-Korean_relations">Inter-Korean relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Inter-Korean_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Inter-Korean relations">Inter-Korean relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_reunification" title="Korean reunification">Korean reunification</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">Korean Demilitarized Zone</a> with South Korea remains the most heavily fortified border in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-border_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-border-182">[178]</a></sup> Inter-Korean relations are at the core of North Korean diplomacy and have seen numerous shifts in the last few decades. North Korea's policy is to seek reunification without what it sees as outside interference, through a federal structure retaining each side's leadership and systems. In 1972, the two Koreas agreed in principle to achieve reunification through peaceful means and without foreign interference.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009218_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009218-183">[179]</a></sup> On 10 October 1980, then North Korean president Kim Il-sung proposed a federation between North and South Korea named the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Federal_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Federal Republic of Korea">Democratic Federal Republic of Korea</a> in which the respective political systems would initially remain.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup> However, relations remained cool well until the early 1990s, with a brief period in the early 1980s when North Korea offered to provide flood relief to its southern neighbor.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> Although the offer was initially welcomed, talks over how to deliver the relief goods broke down and none of the promised aid ever crossed the border.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup> The two countries also organized a reunion of 92 separated families.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009220_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009220-187">[183]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/220px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/330px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/440px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1415" data-file-height="943"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Kim Jong-un and South Korean President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> shake hands during the <a href="/wiki/April_2018_inter-Korean_summit" title="April 2018 inter-Korean summit">inter-Korean Summit</a>, April 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg/170px-501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg/255px-501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg/340px-501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1012" data-file-height="1268"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:501_cows_sent_to_North_Korea.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>South Korean aid convoy entering North Korea through the Demilitarized Zone, 1998
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Sunshine_Policy" title="Sunshine Policy">Sunshine Policy</a> instituted by South Korean president <a href="/wiki/Kim_Dae-jung" title="Kim Dae-jung">Kim Dae-jung</a> in 1998 was a watershed in inter-Korean relations. It encouraged other countries to engage with the North, which allowed Pyongyang to normalize relations with a number of European Union states and contributed to the establishment of joint North-South economic projects. The culmination of the Sunshine Policy was the <a href="/wiki/2000_Inter-Korean_summit" class="mw-redirect" title="2000 Inter-Korean summit">2000 Inter-Korean summit</a>, when Kim Dae-jung visited Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009222_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009222-188">[184]</a></sup> Both North and South Korea signed the <a href="/wiki/June_15th_North%E2%80%93South_Joint_Declaration" title="June 15th North–South Joint Declaration">June 15th North–South Joint Declaration</a>, in which both sides promised to seek peaceful reunification.<sup id="cite_ref-joint_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-joint-189">[185]</a></sup> On 4 October 2007, South Korean president <a href="/wiki/Roh_Moo-hyun" title="Roh Moo-hyun">Roh Moo-hyun</a> and Kim Jong-il signed an eight-point peace agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-idUKSEO16392220071004_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-idUKSEO16392220071004-190">[186]</a></sup> However, relations worsened when South Korean president <a href="/wiki/Lee_Myung-bak" title="Lee Myung-bak">Lee Myung-bak</a> adopted a more hard-line approach and suspended aid deliveries pending the de-nuclearization of the North. In 2009, North Korea responded by ending all of its previous agreements with the South.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup> It deployed additional ballistic missiles<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> and placed its military on full combat alert after South Korea, Japan and the United States threatened to intercept a <a href="/wiki/Unha-2" class="mw-redirect" title="Unha-2">Unha-2</a> space launch vehicle.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup> The next few years witnessed a string of hostilities, including the alleged North Korean involvement in the <a href="/wiki/ROKS_Cheonan_sinking" title="ROKS Cheonan sinking">sinking of South Korean warship <i>Cheonan</i></a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Anger_at_North_Korea_over_sinking_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anger_at_North_Korea_over_sinking-91">[88]</a></sup> mutual ending of diplomatic ties,<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> a North Korean artillery <a href="/wiki/Bombardment_of_Yeonpyeong" title="Bombardment of Yeonpyeong">attack on Yeonpyeong Island</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> and growing international concern over North Korea's nuclear program.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[192]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In May 2017, <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> was elected President of South Korea with a promise to return to the Sunshine Policy.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> In February 2018, a détente developed at the Winter Olympics held in South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-98">[95]</a></sup> In April, South Korean President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> and Kim Jong-un met at the DMZ, and, in the <a href="/wiki/Panmunjom_Declaration" title="Panmunjom Declaration">Panmunjom Declaration</a>, pledged to work for peace and nuclear disarmament.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_pledge_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_pledge-198">[194]</a></sup> In September, at a joint news conference in Pyongyang, Moon and Kim agreed upon turning the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a> into a "land of peace without nuclear weapons and nuclear threats".<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_internal_security">Law enforcement and internal security</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_North_Korea" title="Law enforcement in North Korea">Law enforcement in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_North_Korea" title="Law of North Korea">Law of North Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_North_Korea" title="Judiciary of North Korea">Judiciary of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg/220px-Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg/330px-Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg/440px-Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5312" data-file-height="2988"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Police_car_outside_Okryu_Restaurant.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A North Korean police car in 2017; the <a href="/wiki/Chos%C5%8Fn%27g%C5%ADl" class="mw-redirect" title="Chosŏn'gŭl">Chosŏn'gŭl</a> lettering on the side translates to "Traffic safety".
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea has a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> system based on the <a href="/wiki/General_state_laws_for_the_Prussian_states" class="mw-redirect" title="General state laws for the Prussian states">Prussian model</a> and influenced by Japanese traditions and communist legal theory.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judiciary</a> procedures are handled by the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Court of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Supreme Court</a> (the highest <a href="/wiki/Court_of_appeal" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of appeal">court of appeal</a>), provincial or special city-level courts, people's courts and special courts. People's courts are at the lowest level of the system and operate in cities, counties and urban districts, while different kinds of special courts handle cases related to military, railroad or maritime matters.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009274_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009274-201">[197]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Judges are theoretically elected by their respective local people's assemblies, but in practice they are appointed by the Workers' Party of Korea. The <a href="/wiki/Penal_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Penal code">penal code</a> is based on the principle of <i><a href="/wiki/Nullum_crimen,_nulla_poena_sine_praevia_lege_poenali" class="mw-redirect" title="Nullum crimen, nulla poena sine praevia lege poenali">nullum crimen sine lege</a></i> (no crime without a law), but remains a tool for political control despite several amendments reducing ideological influence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009274_201-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009274-201">[197]</a></sup> Courts carry out legal procedures related to not only criminal and civil matters, but also political cases as well.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009201_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009201-202">[198]</a></sup> Political prisoners are sent to <a href="/wiki/Labor_camp" title="Labor camp">labor camps</a>, while criminal offenders are incarcerated in a separate system.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[199]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_Security_(North_Korea)" title="Ministry of Social Security (North Korea)">Ministry of People's Security</a> (MPS) maintains most law enforcement activities. It is one of the most powerful state institutions in North Korea and oversees the national police force, investigates criminal cases and manages non-political correctional facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009276_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009276-204">[200]</a></sup> It handles other aspects of domestic security like civil registration, traffic control, fire departments and railroad security.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009277_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009277-205">[201]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/State_Security_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="State Security Department">State Security Department</a> was separated from the MPS in 1973 to conduct domestic and foreign intelligence, counterintelligence and manage the political prison system. Political camps can be short-term reeducation zones or "<a href="/wiki/Kwalliso" title="Kwalliso">kwalliso</a>" (total control zones) for lifetime detention.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009277–278_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009277–278-206">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yodok_concentration_camp" title="Yodok concentration camp">Camp 15 in Yodok</a><sup id="cite_ref-csw_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csw-207">[203]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bukchang_concentration_camp" class="mw-redirect" title="Bukchang concentration camp">Camp 18 in Bukchang</a><sup id="cite_ref-sub_ihr_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sub_ihr-208">[204]</a></sup> have been described in detailed testimonies.<sup id="cite_ref-hrnk2_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrnk2-209">[205]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The security apparatus is very extensive,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272-210">[206]</a></sup> exerting strict control over residence, travel, employment, clothing, food and family life.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009273_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009273-211">[207]</a></sup> Security forces employ <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_North_Korea" title="Mass surveillance in North Korea">mass surveillance</a>. It is believed they tightly monitor cellular and digital communications.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[208]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_North_Korea" title="Human rights in North Korea">Human rights in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Prisons_in_North_Korea" title="Prisons in North Korea">Prisons in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r997900035">.mw-parser-output .locmap .od{position:absolute}.mw-parser-output .locmap .id{position:absolute;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .locmap .l0{font-size:0;position:absolute}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pv{line-height:110%;position:absolute;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pl{line-height:110%;position:absolute;top:-0.75em;text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pr{line-height:110%;position:absolute;top:-0.75em;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pv>div{display:inline;padding:1px}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pl>div{display:inline;padding:1px;float:right}.mw-parser-output .locmap .pr>div{display:inline;padding:1px;float:left}</style>
      <div class="locmap noviewer thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px">
        <div style="position:relative;width:240px;border:1px solid lightgray">
         <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg" class="image" title="North Korea is located in North Korea"><img alt="North Korea is located in North Korea" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg/240px-North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="241" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg/360px-North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg/480px-North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1606" data-file-height="1616"></a>
         <div class="od" style="top:65.857%;left:30.342%">
          <div class="id" style="left:-4px;top:-4px">
           <img alt="Pukchang" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Pukchang" width="8" height="8" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="64" data-file-height="64">

         </div>
         <div class="od" style="top:23.974%;left:82.729%">

          </div>

           <div>
            <a href="/wiki/Chongjin_concentration_camp" title="Chongjin concentration camp">Chongjin</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="od" style="top:11.615%;left:85.816%">
          <div class="id" style="left:-4px;top:-4px">
           <img alt="Hoeryong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Hoeryong" width="8" height="8" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="64" data-file-height="64">

         <div class="od" style="top:33.886%;left:77.812%">
          <div class="id" style="left:-4px;top:-4px">
           <img alt="Hwasong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Hwasong" width="8" height="8" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="64" data-file-height="64">
          </div>
          <div class="pl" style="font-size:91%;width:6em;right:5px">
           <div>
            <a href="/wiki/Hwasong_concentration_camp" title="Hwasong concentration camp">Hwasong</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="od" style="top:63.665%;left:28.757%">
          <div class="id" style="left:-4px;top:-4px">
           <img alt="Kaechon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Kaechon" width="8" height="8" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="64" data-file-height="64">
          </div>
          <div class="pl" style="font-size:91%;width:6em;right:5px">
           <div>
            <a href="/wiki/Kaechon_internment_camp" title="Kaechon internment camp">Kaechon</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="od" style="top:61.857%;left:40.462%">
          <div class="id" style="left:-4px;top:-4px">
           <img alt="Yodok" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Yodok" width="8" height="8" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="64" data-file-height="64">
          </div>
          <div class="pr" style="font-size:91%;width:6em;left:5px">
           <div>
            <a href="/wiki/Yodok_concentration_camp" title="Yodok concentration camp">Yodok</a>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_adm_location_map.svg" title="File:North Korea adm location map.svg"> </a>
         </div>A map of political prison camps in North Korea. An estimated 40% of prisoners die of malnutrition.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[209]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea is widely accused of having perhaps the worst <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> record in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Amnesty_International_2007_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amnesty_International_2007-27">[24]</a></sup> A 2014 UN inquiry into <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_North_Korea" title="Human rights in North Korea">human rights in North Korea</a> concluded that, "The gravity, scale and nature of these violations reveal a state that does not have any parallel in the contemporary world".<sup id="cite_ref-ohchr.org_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ohchr.org-28">[25]</a></sup> North Koreans have been referred to as "some of the world's most brutalized people" by <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a>, because of the severe restrictions placed on their <a href="/wiki/Freedom_(political)" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom (political)">political</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_freedom" title="Economic freedom">economic freedoms</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hrw1_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw1-29">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hrw2_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw2-30">[27]</a></sup> The North Korean population is strictly managed by the state and all aspects of daily life are subordinated to party and state planning. Employment is managed by the party on the basis of political reliability, and travel is tightly controlled by the Ministry of People's Security.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272–273_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272–273-214">[210]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> reports of severe restrictions on the freedom of association, expression and movement, arbitrary detention, torture and other ill-treatment resulting in death, and executions.<sup id="cite_ref-ai1_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ai1-215">[211]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/State_Security_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="State Security Department">State Security Department</a> extrajudicially apprehends and imprisons those accused of political crimes without due process.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009278_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009278-216">[212]</a></sup> People perceived as hostile to the government, such as Christians or critics of the leadership,<sup id="cite_ref-ai_ppc_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ai_ppc-217">[213]</a></sup> are deported to labor camps without trial,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup> often with their whole family and mostly without any chance of being released.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Based on satellite images and defector testimonies, Amnesty International estimates that around 200,000 prisoners are held in six large political prison camps,<sup id="cite_ref-ai_ppc_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ai_ppc-217">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ai2_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ai2-220">[216]</a></sup> where they are forced to work in conditions approaching slavery.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup> Supporters of the government who deviate from the government line are subject to <a href="/wiki/Reeducation_through_labor" class="mw-redirect" title="Reeducation through labor">reeducation</a> in sections of <a href="/wiki/Labor_camp" title="Labor camp">labor camps</a> set aside for that purpose. Those who are deemed <a href="/wiki/Political_rehabilitation" title="Political rehabilitation">politically rehabilitated</a> may reassume responsible government positions on their release.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[218]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/North_Korean_defectors" title="North Korean defectors">North Korean defectors</a><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[219]</a></sup> have provided detailed testimonies on the existence of the total control zones where abuses such as torture, starvation, rape, murder, <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_human_experimentation" class="mw-redirect" title="North Korean human experimentation">medical experimentation</a>, forced labor, and forced abortions have been reported.<sup id="cite_ref-hrnk2_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrnk2-209">[205]</a></sup> On the basis of these abuses, as well as persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, forcible transfer of populations, enforced disappearance of persons and forced starvation, the <a href="/wiki/Report_of_the_Commission_of_Inquiry_on_Human_Rights_in_the_Democratic_People%E2%80%99s_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea">United Nations Commission of Inquiry</a> has accused North Korea of <a href="/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity" title="Crimes against humanity">crimes against humanity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Coalition_to_Stop_Crimes_Against_Humanity_in_North_Korea" title="International Coalition to Stop Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea">International Coalition to Stop Crimes Against Humanity in North Korea</a> (ICNK) estimates that over 10,000 people die in North Korean prison camps every year.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to Human Rights Watch, which cites interviews with defectors, North Korean women are routinely subjected to sexual violence, unwanted sexual contact, and rape. Men in positions of power, including police, high-ranking officials, market supervisors, and guards can abuse women at will and are not prosecuted for it. It happens so often that it is accepted as a routine part of life. Women assume they can not do anything about it. The only ones with protection are those whose husbands or fathers are themselves in positions of power.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The North Korean government rejects the human rights abuse claims, calling them "a smear campaign" and a "human rights racket" aimed at government change.<sup id="cite_ref-human_rights1_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-human_rights1-229">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-human_rights2_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-human_rights2-230">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SCR212_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCR212-231">[227]</a></sup> In a 2014 report to the UN, North Korea dismissed accusations of atrocities as "wild rumors".<sup id="cite_ref-human_rights4_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-human_rights4-31">[28]</a></sup> The official state media, <a href="/wiki/Korean_Central_News_Agency" title="Korean Central News Agency">KCNA</a>, responded with an article that included homophobic insults against the author of the human rights report, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Kirby_(judge)" title="Michael Kirby (judge)">Michael Kirby</a>, calling him "a disgusting old lecher with a 40-odd-year-long career of homosexuality ... This practice can never be found in the DPRK boasting of the sound mentality and good morals ... In fact, it is ridiculous for such gay [<i><a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">sic</a></i>] to sponsor dealing with others' human rights issue."<sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor-32">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kcna.co.jp_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kcna.co.jp-33">[30]</a></sup> The government, however, admitted some human rights issues related to living conditions and stated that it is working to improve them.<sup id="cite_ref-SCR212_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCR212-231">[227]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to Amnesty International, citizens in North Korea are denied <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_movement" title="Freedom of movement">freedom of movement</a> including the right to leave the country<sup id="cite_ref-:0_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-232">[228]</a></sup> at will and its government denies access to international human rights observers.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>While there is consensus in regards to human human rights abuses being committed in North Korea it is extremely difficult to gauge the full extent due to many defectors testimonies falling apart and the fact that defectors are incentivized through cash payments in return for interviews. Depending on the quality of the information the payments range from $50–500.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[230]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Army" title="Korean People's Army">Korean People's Army</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="North Korea and weapons of mass destruction">North Korea and weapons of mass destruction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Songun" title="Songun">Songun</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_(8179381094).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg/220px-AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg/330px-AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg/440px-AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_%288179381094%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4603" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AIR_KORYO_IL76_P912_AT_SONDOK_HAMHUNG_AIRPORT_DPR_KOREA_OCT_2012_(8179381094).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ilyushin_Il-76" title="Ilyushin Il-76">Ilyushin Il-76</a> strategic military airlifter used by <a href="/wiki/Air_Koryo" title="Air Koryo">Air Koryo</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Army" title="Korean People's Army">Korean People's Army</a> (KPA) has 1,106,000 active and 8,389,000 reserve and paramilitary troops, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by number of troops">largest military institution in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup> With an active duty army of 1.21 million, consisting of <span data-sort-value="7000473588553466425♠" style="display:none"></span>4.7% of its population, the KPA is the fourth <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">largest military force</a> in the world after China, the United States and India.<sup id="cite_ref-bgn_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bgn-236">[232]</a></sup> About 20 percent of men aged 17–54 serve in the regular armed forces,<sup id="cite_ref-bgn_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bgn-236">[232]</a></sup> and approximately one in every 25 citizens is an enlisted soldier.<sup id="cite_ref-economist-armied_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-armied-237">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup> The KPA has five branches: <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Army_Ground_Force" title="Korean People's Army Ground Force">Ground Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Navy" title="Korean People's Navy">Navy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Air_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean People's Air Force">Air Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_Special_Operation_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="North Korean Special Operation Force">Special Operations Force</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Rocket_Forces_(North_Korea)" class="mw-redirect" title="Strategic Rocket Forces (North Korea)">Rocket Force</a>. Command of the Korean People's Army lies in both the <a href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Central Military Commission of the Workers' Party of Korea">Central Military Commission of the Workers' Party of Korea</a> and the independent State Affairs Commission. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_People%27s_Armed_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of People's Armed Forces">Ministry of People's Armed Forces</a> is subordinated to the latter.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009239_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009239-239">[235]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Of all KPA branches, the Ground Force is the largest. It has approximately one million personnel divided into 80 infantry <a href="/wiki/Division_(military)" title="Division (military)">divisions</a>, 30 artillery <a href="/wiki/Brigade_(military)" class="mw-redirect" title="Brigade (military)">brigades</a>, 25 special warfare brigades, 20 mechanized brigades, 10 tank brigades and seven tank <a href="/wiki/Regiment" title="Regiment">regiments</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009247_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009247-240">[236]</a></sup> They are equipped with 3,700 tanks, 2,100 <a href="/wiki/Armored_personnel_carrier" class="mw-redirect" title="Armored personnel carrier">armored personnel carriers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Infantry_fighting_vehicle" title="Infantry fighting vehicle">infantry fighting vehicles</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009248_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009248-241">[237]</a></sup> 17,900 artillery pieces, 11,000 anti-aircraft guns<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile200719_–_Major_Military_Equipment_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile200719_–_Major_Military_Equipment-242">[238]</a></sup> and some 10,000 <a href="/wiki/MANPADS" class="mw-redirect" title="MANPADS">MANPADS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anti-tank_guided_missile" title="Anti-tank guided missile">anti-tank guided missiles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup> Other equipment includes 1,600 aircraft in the Air Force and 1,000 vessels in the Navy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009249–253_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009249–253-244">[240]</a></sup> North Korea has the largest special forces and the largest submarine fleet in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009288–293_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009288–293-245">[241]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG/170px-Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG/255px-Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG/340px-Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2616" data-file-height="3488"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mansudae_Grand_Monument_26.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Memorial of Soldiers at the Mansudae Grand Monument
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea possesses nuclear weapons,<sup id="cite_ref-economist-armied_237-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-armied-237">[233]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[242]</a></sup> but the strength of its arsenal is uncertain. In January 2018, estimates of North Korea's nuclear arsenal ranged between 15 and 60 bombs, probably including <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_bombs" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydrogen bombs">hydrogen bombs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-95">[92]</a></sup> Delivery capabilities<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup> are provided by the Rocket Force, which has some 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile" title="Ballistic missile">ballistic missiles</a> with a range of up to 7,400 miles (11,900&nbsp;km).<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2004 South Korean assessment, North Korea possesses a stockpile of <a href="/wiki/Chemical_weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Chemical weapons">chemical weapons</a> estimated to amount to 2,500–5,000 tons, including nerve, blister, blood, and vomiting agents, as well as the ability to cultivate and produce <a href="/wiki/Biological_weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Biological weapons">biological weapons</a> including <a href="/wiki/Anthrax" title="Anthrax">anthrax</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009260_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009260-249">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[246]</a></sup> Because of its nuclear and missile tests, North Korea has been <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_Security_Council_resolutions_concerning_North_Korea" title="List of United Nations Security Council resolutions concerning North Korea">sanctioned under United Nations Security Council resolutions</a> <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1695" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 1695">1695</a> of July 2006, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1718" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 1718">1718</a> of October 2006, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1874" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 1874">1874</a> of June 2009, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2087" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 2087">2087</a> of January 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-secu_UNDo_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-secu_UNDo-251">[247]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2397" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 2397">2397</a> in December 2017. </p>
      <p>The military faces some issues limiting its conventional capabilities, including obsolete equipment, insufficient fuel supplies and a shortage of digital <a href="/wiki/Command_and_control" title="Command and control">command and control</a> assets due to other countries being banned from selling weapons to it by the UN sanctions.
