To compensate for these deficiencies, the KPA has deployed a wide range of <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_warfare" title="Asymmetric warfare">asymmetric warfare</a> technologies like anti-personnel blinding lasers,<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/GPS" class="mw-redirect" title="GPS">GPS</a> jammers,<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Midget_submarine" title="Midget submarine">midget submarines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_torpedo" title="Human torpedo">human torpedoes</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stealth_technology" title="Stealth technology">stealth</a> paint,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cyberwarfare" title="Cyberwarfare">cyberwarfare</a> units.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[253]</a></sup> In 2015, North Korea was estimated as having 6,000 sophisticated computer security personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[254]</a></sup> KPA units have allegedly attempted to jam South Korean <a href="/wiki/Military_satellite" title="Military satellite">military satellites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Much of the equipment is engineered and produced by <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_North_Korea" title="Defense industry of North Korea">a domestic defense industry</a>. Weapons are manufactured in roughly 1,800 underground defense industry plants scattered throughout the country, most of them located in <a href="/wiki/Chagang_Province" title="Chagang Province">Chagang Province</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> The defense industry is capable of producing a full range of individual and crew-served weapons, artillery, armored vehicles, tanks, missiles, helicopters, surface combatants, submarines, landing and infiltration craft, <a href="/wiki/Yak-18" class="mw-redirect" title="Yak-18">Yak-18</a> trainers and possibly co-production of jet aircraft.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009272-210">[206]</a></sup> According to official North Korean media, military expenditures for 2010 amount to 15.8 percent of the state budget.<sup id="cite_ref-kcna2010budget_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kcna2010budget-261">[257]</a></sup> The U.S. State Department has estimated that North Korea's military spending averaged 23% of its GDP from 2004 to 2014, the highest level in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[258]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to Military Watch Magazine's military strength list, DPR Korea has the sixth most powerful military, placing it in the "Tier 2" military powers group.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[259]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_North_Korea" title="Demographics of North Korea">Demographics of North Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_North_Korea" title="Ethnic minorities in North Korea">Ethnic minorities in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;">Population<sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-10">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2019_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2019-11">[9]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Million </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1950</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">10.5 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2000</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">22.9 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2018</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">25.5 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png/220px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png/330px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png/440px-Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png 2x" data-file-width="610" data-file-height="425"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bev%C3%B6lkerungspyramide_Nordkorea_2016.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population pyramid in 2016
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With the exception of a small <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">Chinese</a> community and a few ethnic <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese</a>, North Korea's 25,549,604<sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-10">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2019_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2019-11">[9]</a></sup> people are ethnically homogeneous.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> Demographic experts in the 20th century estimated that the population would grow to 25.5 million by 2000 and 28 million by 2010, but this increase never occurred due to the <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_famine" title="North Korean famine">North Korean famine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969-265">[261]</a></sup> It began in 1995, lasted for three years and resulted in the deaths of between 240,000 and 420,000 North Koreans.<sup id="cite_ref-Spoorenberg_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spoorenberg-84">[81]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>International donors led by the United States initiated shipments of food through the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="World Food Program">World Food Program</a> in 1997 to combat the famine.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup> Despite a drastic reduction of aid under the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush" title="Presidency of George W. Bush">George W. Bush administration</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup> the situation gradually improved: the number of malnourished children declined from 60% in 1998<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii-268">[264]</a></sup> to 37% in 2006<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup> and 28% in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup> Domestic food production almost recovered to the recommended annual level of 5.37 million tons of cereal equivalent in 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> but the World Food Program reported a continuing lack of dietary diversity and access to fats and proteins.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[268]</a></sup> By the mid-2010s national levels of severe wasting an indication of famine-like conditions were lower than in other low-income countries and about on par with developing nations in the Pacific and East Asia. Children’s health and nutrition is significantly better on a number of indicators than in many other Asian countries.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[269]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The famine had a significant impact on the population growth rate, which declined to 0.9% annually in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969-265">[261]</a></sup> It was 0.5% in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[270]</a></sup> Late marriages after military service, limited housing space and long hours of work or political studies further exhaust the population and reduce growth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969_265-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200969-265">[261]</a></sup> The national birth rate is 14.5 births per year per 1,000 population.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> Two-thirds of households consist of <a href="/wiki/Extended_family" title="Extended family">extended families</a> mostly living in two-room units. <a href="/wiki/Marriage" title="Marriage">Marriage</a> is virtually universal and <a href="/wiki/Divorce" title="Divorce">divorce</a> is extremely rare.<sup id="cite_ref-PRB_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRB-276">[272]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_North_Korea" title="Health in North Korea">Health in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg/220px-North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg/330px-North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg/440px-North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1504" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea-Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital-04.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A dental clinic at <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_Maternity_Hospital" title="Pyongyang Maternity Hospital">Pyongyang Maternity Hospital</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea has a life expectancy of 72.3 years in 2019, according to HDR 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup> While North Korea is classified as a low-income country, the structure of North Korea's causes of death (2013) is unlike that of other low-income countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases-278">[274]</a></sup> Instead, it is closer to worldwide averages, with non-communicable diseases—such as cardiovascular disease and cancers—accounting for 84 percent of the total deaths in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the World Bank report of 2016 (based on <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">WHO</a>'s estimate), only 9.5% of the total deaths recorded in North Korea are attributed to communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions, a figure which is slightly lower than that of South Korea (10.1%) and one fifth of other low-income countries (50.1%) but higher than that of high income countries (6.7%).<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup> Only one out of ten leading causes of overall deaths in North Korea is attributed to communicable diseases (<a href="/wiki/Lower_respiratory_tract_infection" title="Lower respiratory tract infection">lower respiratory infection</a>), a disease which is reported to have declined by six percent since 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-281">[277]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a> as a single disease group was reported as the largest cause of death in North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases-278">[274]</a></sup> The three major causes of death in North Korea are <a href="/wiki/Stroke" title="Stroke">stroke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chronic_obstructive_pulmonary_disease" title="Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease">COPD</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease" title="Coronary artery disease">Ischaemic heart disease</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-281">[277]</a></sup> Non-communicable diseases risk factors in North Korea include high rates of urbanization, an aging society, and high rates of <a href="/wiki/Smoking" title="Smoking">smoking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alcoholic_beverage" class="mw-redirect" title="Alcoholic beverage">alcohol</a> consumption amongst men.<sup id="cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases-278">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Maternal mortality is lower than other low-income countries, but significantly higher than South Korea and other high income countries, at 89 per 100,000 live births.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[278]</a></sup> In 2008 child mortality was estimated to be 45 per 1,000 this is much better than other economically comparable countries, <a href="/wiki/Chad" title="Chad">Chad</a> for example had a child mortality rate of 120 per 1,000, this is despite the fact that Chad was most likely wealthier than North Korea at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-78">[75]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/healthcare-access-and-quality-index">Healthcare Access and Quality Index</a>, calculated by <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation" title="Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation">IHME</a>, was reported to stand at 62.3, much lower than that of South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[279]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2003 report by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">United States Department of State</a>, almost 100% of the population has access to water and sanitation.<sup id="cite_ref-Life_Inside_North_Korea_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Life_Inside_North_Korea-284">[280]</a></sup> 80% of the population had access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">improved sanitation</a> facilities in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[281]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea has the highest number of doctors per capita amongst low-income countries, with 3.7 physicians per 1,000 people, a figure which is also significantly higher than that of South Korea, according to <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">WHO</a>'s data.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Conflicting reports between Amnesty and WHO have emerged where the Amnesty report claimed that North Korea had an inadequate health care system. On the contrary, the Director of the World Health Organization claimed that North Korea's healthcare system was considered the envy of the developing world and had "no lack of doctors and nurses".<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A free universal insurance system is in place.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20077–8_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20077–8-288">[284]</a></sup> Quality of medical care varies significantly by region<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009127_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009127-289">[285]</a></sup> and is often low, with severe shortages of equipment, drugs and anesthetics.<sup id="cite_ref-cha_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cha-290">[286]</a></sup> According to WHO, expenditure on health per capita is one of the lowest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-cha_290-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cha-290">[286]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Preventive_healthcare" title="Preventive healthcare">Preventive medicine</a> is emphasized through physical exercise and sports, nationwide monthly checkups and routine spraying of public places against disease. Every individual has a lifetime health card which contains a full medical record.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009126_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009126-291">[287]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_North_Korea" title="Education in North Korea">Education in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_(7968604172).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg/220px-Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg/330px-Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg/440px-Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_%287968604172%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4921" data-file-height="3286"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Laika_ac_Grand_People%27s_Study_House_(7968604172).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>English lecture at the <a href="/wiki/Grand_People%27s_Study_House" title="Grand People's Study House">Grand People's Study House</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/2008_North_Korea_census" class="mw-redirect" title="2008 North Korea census">2008 census</a> listed the entire population as literate.<sup id="cite_ref-PRB_276-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRB-276">[272]</a></sup> An 11-year free, compulsory cycle of primary and secondary education is provided in more than 27,000 <a href="/wiki/Nursery_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Nursery school">nursery schools</a>, 14,000 <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergartens</a>, 4,800 four-year primary and 4,700 six-year secondary schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii-268">[264]</a></sup> 77% of males and 79% of females aged 30–34 have finished secondary school.<sup id="cite_ref-PRB_276-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRB-276">[272]</a></sup> An additional 300 universities and colleges offer <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher education</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii_268-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii-268">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most graduates from the compulsory program do not attend university but begin their obligatory military service or proceed to work in farms or factories instead. The main deficiencies of higher education are the heavy presence of ideological subjects, which comprise 50% of courses in social studies and 20% in sciences,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009122_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009122-292">[288]</a></sup> and the imbalances in curriculum. The study of natural sciences is greatly emphasized while social sciences are neglected.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009123_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009123-293">[289]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Heuristics" class="mw-redirect" title="Heuristics">Heuristics</a> is actively applied to develop the independence and creativity of students throughout the system.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup> The study of <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> was made compulsory in upper middle schools in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009124_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009124-295">[291]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="***REMOVED***">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_differences_in_the_Korean_language" title="North–South differences in the Korean language">North–South differences in the Korean language</a>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea shares the <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean language</a> with South Korea, although some <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_differences_in_the_Korean_language" title="North–South differences in the Korean language">dialectal differences</a> exist within both Koreas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii_268-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxii-268">[264]</a></sup> North Koreans refer to their <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyongyang dialect">Pyongyang dialect</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/Munhwa%C5%8F" class="mw-redirect" title="Munhwaŏ">munhwaŏ</a></i> ("cultured language") as opposed to the dialects of South Korea, especially the <a href="/wiki/Seoul_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Seoul dialect">Seoul dialect</a> or <i>p'yojun'ŏ</i> ("standard language"), which are viewed as decadent because of its use of loanwords from <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="European languages">European languages</a> (particularly <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Language_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Language-296">[292]</a></sup> Words of Chinese, Manchu or Western origin have been eliminated from <i>munhwa</i> along with the usage of Chinese <a href="/wiki/Hancha" class="mw-redirect" title="Hancha">hancha</a> characters.<sup id="cite_ref-Language_296-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Language-296">[292]</a></sup> Written language uses only the <a href="/wiki/Chos%C5%8Fn%27g%C5%ADl" class="mw-redirect" title="Chosŏn'gŭl">chosŏn'gŭl</a> (Hangul) phonetic alphabet, developed under <a href="/wiki/Sejong_the_Great" title="Sejong the Great">Sejong the Great</a> (1418–1450).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200918_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200918-297">[293]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_North_Korea" title="Religion in North Korea">Religion in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Chilgol_Church_(15545529301).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg/220px-Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg/330px-Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg/440px-Chilgol_Church_%2815545529301%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4912" data-file-height="2760"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Chilgol_Church_(15545529301).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Chilgol_Church" title="Chilgol Church">Chilgol Church</a> in Pyongyang, where <a href="/wiki/Kang_Pan-sok" title="Kang Pan-sok">Kang Pan-sok</a>—the mother of the late supreme leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>—served as a <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian" class="mw-redirect" title="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a> <a href="/wiki/Deaconess" title="Deaconess">deaconess.</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Officially, North Korea is an <a href="/wiki/Atheist_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheist state">atheist state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cavendish2007_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cavendish2007-298">[294]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PalmerOBrien1993_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PalmerOBrien1993-299">[295]</a></sup> There are no known official statistics of religions in North Korea. According to Religious Intelligence in 2007, 64% of the population are <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">irreligious</a>, 16% practice <a href="/wiki/Korean_shamanism" title="Korean shamanism">Korean shamanism</a>, 14% practice <a href="/wiki/Cheondoism" title="Cheondoism">Chondoism</a>, 4% are <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Buddhist</a>, and 2% are <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Korea" title="Christianity in Korea">Christian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[296]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_North_Korea" title="Freedom of religion in North Korea">Freedom of religion</a> and the right to religious ceremonies are constitutionally guaranteed, but religions are restricted by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009115_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009115-301">[297]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[298]</a></sup> Amnesty International has expressed concerns about religious persecution in North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-232">[228]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Korean_Confucianism" title="Korean Confucianism">Confucianism</a> still influence cultural life.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[300]</a></sup> Chondoism ("Heavenly Way") is an indigenous <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic belief</a> combining elements of Korean shamanism, Buddhism, <a href="/wiki/Taoism_in_Korea" title="Taoism in Korea">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> that is officially represented by the WPK-controlled <a href="/wiki/Chondoist_Chongu_Party" title="Chondoist Chongu Party">Chondoist Chongu Party</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009120_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009120-305">[301]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Open_Doors" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Doors">Open Doors</a> mission, a Protestant-group based in the United States and founded during the Cold War-era, claims the most severe <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">persecution of Christians</a> in the world occurs in North Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-opendoors_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-opendoors-306">[302]</a></sup> Four state-sanctioned churches exist, but critics claim these are showcases for foreigners.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[304]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Formal_ranking_of_citizens.27_loyalty"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Formal_ranking_of_citizens'_loyalty">Formal ranking of citizens' loyalty</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Songbun" title="Songbun">Songbun</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to North Korean documents and refugee testimonies,<sup id="cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRNKSongbun-309">[305]</a></sup> all North Koreans are sorted into groups according to their <a href="/wiki/Songbun" title="Songbun">Songbun</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Ascribed_status" title="Ascribed status">ascribed status</a> system based on a citizen's assessed loyalty to the government. Based on their own behavior and the political, social, and economic background of their family for three generations as well as behavior by relatives within that range, Songbun is allegedly used to determine whether an individual is trusted with responsibility, given opportunities,<sup id="cite_ref-NKSongbun_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKSongbun-310">[306]</a></sup> or even receives adequate food.<sup id="cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRNKSongbun-309">[305]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-H-LH_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-H-LH-311">[307]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Songbun allegedly affects access to educational and employment opportunities and particularly whether a person is eligible to join North Korea's ruling party.<sup id="cite_ref-NKSongbun_310-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKSongbun-310">[306]</a></sup> There are 3 main classifications and about 50 sub-classifications. According to Kim Il-sung, speaking in 1958, the loyal "core class" constituted 25% of the North Korean population, the "wavering class" 55%, and the "hostile class" 20%.<sup id="cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRNKSongbun-309">[305]</a></sup> The highest status is accorded to individuals descended from those who participated with Kim Il-sung in the resistance against Japanese occupation during and before World War II and to those who were factory workers, laborers, or peasants in 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-BRHLH_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BRHLH-312">[308]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>While some analysts believe private commerce recently changed the Songbun system to some extent,<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> most North Korean refugees say it remains a commanding presence in everyday life.<sup id="cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRNKSongbun-309">[305]</a></sup> The North Korean government claims all citizens are equal and denies any discrimination on the basis of family background.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[310]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_North_Korea" title="Economy of North Korea">Economy of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea has maintained one of the most closed and centralized economies in the world since the 1940s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009135_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009135-315">[311]</a></sup> For several decades, it followed the Soviet pattern of five-year plans with the ultimate goal of achieving self-sufficiency. Extensive Soviet and Chinese support allowed North Korea to rapidly recover from the Korean War and register very high growth rates. Systematic inefficiency began to arise around 1960, when the economy shifted from the <a href="/wiki/Extensive_growth" title="Extensive growth">extensive</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Intensive_growth" class="mw-redirect" title="Intensive growth">intensive development</a> stage. The shortage of skilled labor, energy, arable land and transportation significantly impeded long-term growth and resulted in consistent failure to meet planning objectives.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009138_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009138-316">[312]</a></sup> The major slowdown of the economy contrasted with South Korea, which surpassed the North in terms of absolute <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> and per capita income by the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009142_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009142-317">[313]</a></sup> North Korea declared the last seven-year plan unsuccessful in December 1993 and thereafter stopped announcing plans.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009140_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009140-318">[314]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Industry_Hamhung,_North_Korea.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg/220px-Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg/330px-Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg/440px-Industry_Hamhung%2C_North_Korea.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2836" data-file-height="1890"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Industry_Hamhung,_North_Korea.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An industrial plant in <a href="/wiki/Hamhung" title="Hamhung">Hamhung</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The loss of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> trading partners and a series of natural disasters throughout the 1990s caused severe hardships, including widespread <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a>. By 2000, the situation improved owing to a massive international food assistance effort, but the economy continues to suffer from food shortages, dilapidated infrastructure and a critically low energy supply.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_Economy_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB_Economy-319">[315]</a></sup> In an attempt to recover from the collapse, the government began structural reforms in 1998 that formally legalized <a href="/wiki/Private_property" title="Private property">private ownership</a> of assets and decentralized control over production.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009143,_145_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009143,_145-320">[316]</a></sup> A second round of reforms in 2002 led to an expansion of market activities, partial <a href="/wiki/Monetization" title="Monetization">monetization</a>, flexible prices and salaries, and the introduction of incentives and accountability techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20079_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20079-321">[317]</a></sup> Despite these changes, North Korea remains a <a href="/wiki/Command_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Command economy">command economy</a> where the state owns almost all means of production and development priorities are defined by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_Economy_319-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB_Economy-319">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea has the structural profile of a relatively industrialized country<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009145_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009145-322">[318]</a></sup> where nearly half of the <a href="/wiki/Gross_Domestic_Product" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross Domestic Product">Gross Domestic Product</a> is generated by <a href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial sector">industry</a><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[319]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">human development</a> is at medium levels.<sup id="cite_ref-HDI_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-324">[320]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">Purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) GDP is estimated at $40 billion,<sup id="cite_ref-CIAGDP(PPP)_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAGDP(PPP)-13">[11]</a></sup> with a very low per capita value of $1,800.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAGDP(PPP)Capita_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAGDP(PPP)Capita-14">[12]</a></sup> In 2012, <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">Gross national income</a> per capita was $1,523, compared to $28,430 in South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[321]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_won" title="North Korean won">North Korean won</a> is the national currency, issued by the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" title="Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003931_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003931-326">[322]</a></sup> The economy has been developing dramatically in recent years despite sanctions according to the <a href="/wiki/Sejong_Institute" title="Sejong Institute">Sejong Institute</a> these changes have been "astonishing".<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The economy is heavily nationalized.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxiii_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009xxiii-328">[324]</a></sup> Food and housing are extensively subsidized by the state; education and healthcare are free;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20077–8_288-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Profile20077–8-288">[284]</a></sup> and the payment of taxes was officially abolished in 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-taxfree_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taxfree-329">[325]</a></sup> A variety of goods are available in department stores and supermarkets in Pyongyang,<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[326]</a></sup> though most of the population relies on small-scale <i><a href="/wiki/Jangmadang" title="Jangmadang">jangmadang</a></i> markets.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[328]</a></sup> In 2009, the government attempted to stem the expanding free market by banning jangmadang and the use of foreign currency,<sup id="cite_ref-EB_Economy_319-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB_Economy-319">[315]</a></sup> heavily devaluing the won and restricting the convertibility of savings in the old currency,<sup id="cite_ref-cha_290-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cha-290">[286]</a></sup> but the resulting <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> spike and rare public protests caused a reversal of these policies.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[329]</a></sup> Private trade is dominated by women because most men are required to be present at their workplace, even though many state-owned enterprises are non-operational.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_(12300043424).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg/220px-Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg/330px-Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg/440px-Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_%2812300043424%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3568" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Masikryong_North_Korea_Ski_Resort_(12300043424).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Foreign tourists in <a href="/wiki/Masikryong_Ski_Resort" title="Masikryong Ski Resort">Masikryong Ski Resort</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Industry and services employ 65%<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[331]</a></sup> of North Korea's 12.6 million labor force.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> Major industries include machine building, military equipment, chemicals, mining, metallurgy, textiles, food processing and tourism.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">Iron ore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a> production are among the few sectors where North Korea performs significantly better than its <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">southern neighbor</a>—it produces about 10 times larger amounts of each resource.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup> Using ex-Romanian drilling rigs, several oil exploration companies have confirmed significant oil reserves in the North Korean shelf of the Sea of Japan, and in areas south of Pyongyang.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The agricultural sector was shattered by the natural disasters of the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009154_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009154-339">[335]</a></sup> Its 3,500 <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_cooperative" title="Agricultural cooperative">cooperatives</a> and state farms<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009143_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009143-340">[336]</a></sup> were among the most productive and successful in the world around 1980<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200947_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200947-341">[337]</a></sup> but now experience chronic <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertilizer</a> and equipment shortages. Rice, corn, soybeans and <a href="/wiki/Potato_production_in_North_Korea" title="Potato production in North Korea">potatoes</a> are some of the primary crops.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_Economy_319-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB_Economy-319">[315]</a></sup> A significant contribution to the food supply comes from commercial fishing and <a href="/wiki/Aquaculture" title="Aquaculture">aquaculture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_Economy_319-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB_Economy-319">[315]</a></sup> Tourism has been a growing sector for the past decade.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup> North Korea has been aiming to increase the number of foreign visitors through projects like the <a href="/wiki/Masikryong_Ski_Resort" title="Masikryong Ski Resort">Masikryong Ski Resort</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Foreign trade surpassed pre-crisis levels in 2005 and continues to expand.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009173_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009173-344">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[341]</a></sup> North Korea has a number of special economic zones (SEZs) and <a href="/wiki/Special_cities_of_North_Korea" title="Special cities of North Korea">Special Administrative Regions</a> where foreign companies can operate with tax and tariff incentives while North Korean establishments gain access to improved technology.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009165_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009165-346">[342]</a></sup> Initially four such zones existed, but they yielded little overall success.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[343]</a></sup> The SEZ system was overhauled in 2013 when 14 new zones were opened and the <a href="/wiki/Rason_Special_Economic_Zone" title="Rason Special Economic Zone">Rason Special Economic Zone</a> was reformed as a joint Chinese-North Korean project.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[344]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kaesong_Industrial_Region" title="Kaesong Industrial Region">Kaesong Industrial Region</a> is a special economic zone where more than 100 South Korean companies employ some 52,000 North Korean workers.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[345]</a></sup> As of August&nbsp;2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=North_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, China is the biggest trading partner of North Korea outside inter-Korean trade, accounting for more than 84% of the total external trade ($5.3 billion) followed by <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> at 3.3% share ($205 million).<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup> In 2014, Russia wrote off 90% of North Korea's debt and the two countries agreed to conduct all transactions in <a href="/wiki/Russian_ruble" title="Russian ruble">rubles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> Overall, external trade in 2013 reached a total of $7.3 billion (the highest amount since 1990<sup id="cite_ref-IFES1_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFES1-352">[348]</a></sup>), while inter-Korean trade dropped to an eight-year low of $1.1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-ft-20140220_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ft-20140220-353">[349]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_North_Korea" title="Energy in North Korea">Energy in North Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_North_Korea" title="Transport in North Korea">Transport in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg/220px-Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg/330px-Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg/440px-Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1345" data-file-height="1452"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Korean_Peninsula_at_night_from_space.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Satellite image of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a> at night, contrasting use of night-time lighting in North and South Korea. A similar contrast is found when comparing night-time maps of <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>North Korea's energy infrastructure is obsolete and in disrepair. Power shortages are chronic and would not be alleviated even by electricity imports because the poorly maintained grid causes significant losses during transmission.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009146_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009146-355">[351]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">Coal</a> accounts for 70% of primary energy production, followed by <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric power">hydroelectric power</a> with 17%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147-357">[353]</a></sup> The government under Kim Jong-un has increased emphasis on renewable energy projects like wind farms, solar parks, solar heating and <a href="/wiki/Biomass" title="Biomass">biomass</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IFES2_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFES2-358">[354]</a></sup> A set of legal regulations adopted in 2014 stressed the development of geothermal, wind and solar energy along with <a href="/wiki/Recycling" title="Recycling">recycling</a> and environmental conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-IFES2_358-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFES2-358">[354]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[355]</a></sup> North Korea's long-term objective is to curb fossil fuel usage and reach an output of 5 million <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Kilowatt">kilowatts</a> from renewable sources by 2044, up from its current total of 430,000 kilowatts from all sources. Wind power is projected to satisfy 15% of the country's total energy demand under this strategy.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea also strives to develop its own civilian nuclear program. These efforts are under much international dispute due to their military applications and concerns about safety.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg/220px-DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg/330px-DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg/440px-DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:DPRK_M62_Naeyeon_706.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A Soviet-built <a href="/wiki/M62_locomotive" title="M62 locomotive">M62</a> diesel unit at <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_Station" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyongyang Station">Pyongyang Station</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg/220px-Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg/330px-Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg/440px-Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="934"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tupolev_Tu-204-300_of_Air_Koryo_at_Vladivostok_Airport_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tupolev_Tu-204" title="Tupolev Tu-204">Tupolev Tu-204</a> of Air Koryo over Vladivostok Airport
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Transport infrastructure includes railways, highways, water and air routes, but rail transport is by far the most widespread. North Korea has some 5,200 kilometers of railways mostly in <a href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" class="mw-redirect" title="Standard gauge">standard gauge</a> which carry 80% of annual passenger traffic and 86% of freight, but electricity shortages undermine their efficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147_357-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147-357">[353]</a></sup> Construction of a <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed railway</a> connecting Kaesong, Pyongyang and <a href="/wiki/Sinuiju" title="Sinuiju">Sinuiju</a> with speeds exceeding 200&nbsp;km/h was approved in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-NKT_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKT-362">[358]</a></sup> North Korea connects with the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> through <a href="/wiki/Rajin_station" title="Rajin station">Rajin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NKT_362-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NKT-362">[358]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Road transport is very limited—only 724 kilometers of the 25,554 kilometer road network are paved,<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup> and maintenance on most roads is poor.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009150_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009150-364">[360]</a></sup> Only 2% of the freight capacity is supported by river and sea transport, and air traffic is negligible.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147_357-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147-357">[353]</a></sup> All port facilities are ice-free and host a merchant fleet of 158 vessels.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[361]</a></sup> Eighty-two airports<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[362]</a></sup> and 23 helipads<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[363]</a></sup> are operational and the largest serve the state-run airline, <a href="/wiki/Air_Koryo" title="Air Koryo">Air Koryo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147_357-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009147-357">[353]</a></sup> Cars are relatively rare,<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[364]</a></sup> but bicycles are common.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[366]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Korean_Committee_of_Space_Technology" title="Korean Committee of Space Technology">Korean Committee of Space Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_North_Korea" title="Telecommunications in North Korea">Telecommunications in North Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/National_Aerospace_Development_Administration" title="National Aerospace Development Administration">National Aerospace Development Administration</a>
      </div> 
      <p>R&amp;D efforts are concentrated at the State Academy of Sciences, which runs 40 research institutes, 200 smaller research centers, a scientific equipment factory and six publishing houses.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup> The government considers science and technology to be directly linked to economic development.<sup id="cite_ref-IFES3_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFES3-372">[368]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[369]</a></sup> A five-year scientific plan emphasizing IT, biotechnology, nanotechnology, marine and plasma research was carried out in the early 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-IFES3_372-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IFES3-372">[368]</a></sup> A 2010 report by the South Korean Science and Technology Policy Institute identified <a href="/wiki/Polymer_chemistry" title="Polymer chemistry">polymer chemistry</a>, single carbon materials, <a href="/wiki/Nanoscience" class="mw-redirect" title="Nanoscience">nanoscience</a>, mathematics, software, nuclear technology and rocketry as potential areas of inter-Korean scientific cooperation. North Korean institutes are strong in these fields of research, although their engineers require additional training and laboratories need equipment upgrades.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[370]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg/170px-North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg/255px-North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg/340px-North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="960"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_Unha-3_rocket_at_launch_pad.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Unha-3" class="mw-redirect" title="Unha-3">Unha-3</a> space launch vehicle at Sohae Satellite Launching Station
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Under its "constructing a powerful <a href="/wiki/Knowledge_economy" title="Knowledge economy">knowledge economy</a>" slogan, the state has launched a project to concentrate education, scientific research and production into a number of "high-tech development zones". International sanctions remain a significant obstacle to their development.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[371]</a></sup> The <i>Miraewon</i> network of <a href="/wiki/Electronic_library" class="mw-redirect" title="Electronic library">electronic libraries</a> was established in 2014 under similar slogans.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[372]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Significant resources have been allocated to the national space program, which is managed by the <a href="/wiki/National_Aerospace_Development_Administration" title="National Aerospace Development Administration">National Aerospace Development Administration</a> (formerly managed by the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Committee_of_Space_Technology" title="Korean Committee of Space Technology">Korean Committee of Space Technology</a> until April 2013)<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spacerace_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spacerace-378">[374]</a></sup> Domestically produced <a href="/wiki/Space_launch_vehicle" class="mw-redirect" title="Space launch vehicle">launch vehicles</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng_program" title="Kwangmyŏngsŏng program">Kwangmyŏngsŏng satellite class</a> are launched from two <a href="/wiki/Spaceport" title="Spaceport">spaceports</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Tonghae_Satellite_Launching_Ground" title="Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground">Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sohae_Satellite_Launching_Station" title="Sohae Satellite Launching Station">Sohae Satellite Launching Station</a>. After four failed attempts, North Korea became the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">tenth spacefaring nation</a> with the launch of <a href="/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng-3_Unit_2" title="Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2">Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2</a> in December 2012, which successfully reached orbit but was believed to be crippled and non-operational.<sup id="cite_ref-ap20121218_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ap20121218-379">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[376]</a></sup> It joined the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Space_Treaty" title="Outer Space Treaty">Outer Space Treaty</a> in 2009<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[377]</a></sup> and has stated its intentions to undertake <a href="/wiki/Human_spaceflight" title="Human spaceflight">crewed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_the_Moon" title="Exploration of the Moon">Moon missions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Spacerace_378-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spacerace-378">[374]</a></sup> The government insists the space program is for peaceful purposes, but the United States, Japan, South Korea and other countries maintain that it serves to advance military ballistic missile programs.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 7 February 2016, North Korea successfully launched a long-range rocket, supposedly to place a <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a> into orbit. Critics believe that the real purpose of the launch was to test a <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile" title="Ballistic missile">ballistic missile</a>. The launch was strongly condemned by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">UN Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNSecurityCouncilVows_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNSecurityCouncilVows-383">[379]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup> A statement broadcast on Korean Central Television said that a new Earth observation satellite, <a href="/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng-4" title="Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4">Kwangmyongsong-4</a>, had successfully been put into orbit less than 10 minutes after lift-off from the <a href="/wiki/Sohae_Satellite_Launching_Station" title="Sohae Satellite Launching Station">Sohae space center</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_Pyongan_Province" title="North Pyongan Province">North Phyongan province</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNSecurityCouncilVows_383-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNSecurityCouncilVows-383">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Usage of communication technology is controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Post_and_Telecommunications_(North_Korea)" title="Ministry of Post and Telecommunications (North Korea)">Ministry of Post and Telecommunications</a>. An adequate nationwide <a href="/wiki/Fiber-optic_communication" title="Fiber-optic communication">fiber-optic</a> <a href="/wiki/Telephony" title="Telephony">telephone system</a> with 1.18 million fixed lines<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> and expanding mobile coverage is in place.<sup id="cite_ref-CIATelephone_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIATelephone-18">[16]</a></sup> Most phones are installed for senior government officials and installation requires written explanation why the user needs a telephone and how it will be paid for.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrench200722_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrench200722-387">[383]</a></sup> Cellular coverage is available with a <a href="/wiki/3G" title="3G">3G</a> network operated by <a href="/wiki/Koryolink" title="Koryolink">Koryolink</a>, a joint venture with <a href="/wiki/Orascom_Telecom_Holding" class="mw-redirect" title="Orascom Telecom Holding">Orascom Telecom Holding</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-20130426_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-20130426-388">[384]</a></sup> The number of subscribers has increased from 3,000 in 2002<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup> to almost two million in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-20130426_388-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-20130426-388">[384]</a></sup> International calls through either fixed or cellular service are restricted, and <a href="/wiki/Mobile_Web" class="mw-redirect" title="Mobile Web">mobile Internet</a> is not available.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-20130426_388-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-20130426-388">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Internet access itself is limited to a handful of elite users and scientists. Instead, North Korea has a <a href="/wiki/Closed_platform" title="Closed platform">walled garden</a> <a href="/wiki/Intranet" title="Intranet">intranet</a> system called <a href="/wiki/Kwangmyong_(network)" title="Kwangmyong (network)">Kwangmyong</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-20121210_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-20121210-390">[386]</a></sup> which is maintained and monitored by the <a href="/wiki/Korea_Computer_Center" title="Korea Computer Center">Korea Computer Center</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[387]</a></sup> Its content is limited to state media, chat services, message boards,<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-20121210_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-20121210-390">[386]</a></sup> an e-mail service and an estimated 1,000–5,500 websites.<sup id="cite_ref-Bright_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bright-392">[388]</a></sup> Computers employ the <a href="/wiki/Red_Star_OS" title="Red Star OS">Red Star OS</a>, an operating system derived from <a href="/wiki/Linux" title="Linux">Linux</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Shell_(computing)" title="Shell (computing)">user shell</a> visually similar to that of <a href="/wiki/OS_X" class="mw-redirect" title="OS X">OS X</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bright_392-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bright-392">[388]</a></sup> On 19 September 2016, a TLDR project noticed the North Korean Internet DNS data and top-level domain was left open which allowed global DNS zone transfers. A dump of the data discovered was shared on <a href="/wiki/GitHub" title="GitHub">GitHub</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hersher2016_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hersher2016-19">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 8 July 2020, the <i><a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a></i> reported that satellite imagery showed activity at a North Korean facility, which was suspected by researchers of being utilized for building nuclear warheads. The images were captured by Planet Labs and analyzed by experts at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Room_39_and_the_.22Royal_Court.22_economy"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Room_39_and_the_&quot;Royal_Court&quot;_economy">Room 39 and the "Royal Court" economy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Room_39" title="Room 39">Room 39</a>
      </div> 
      <p>According to high-level North Korean defectors, since the 1970s, revenue accumulated through foreign currency, revenue which is wholly separate from the official economic organs of the state, is of economic significance. The scale of its significance remains unknown and is a closely guarded secret, however. More recently, this foreign currency is said to have been also derived from the over 100,000 North Korean migrant workers sent around the world, and who contribute the lionshare of their income to <a href="/wiki/Room_39" title="Room 39">this "Royal Court" fund</a>. Other banking, trade and financial ventures (many of which are illicit) are also said to be significant contributors. The fund is reported to be primarily tasked with providing the capital needed to develop the country's military technology (above all else, its <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_North_Korean_nuclear_program" title="Timeline of the North Korean nuclear program">nuclear weapons program</a>), as well as contributing to a system of "gift giving" for the country's political, military and business elite.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_North_Korea" title="Culture of North Korea">Culture of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Korea" title="Culture of Korea">Culture of Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_(10449400303).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg/220px-Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg/330px-Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg/440px-Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_%2810449400303%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3568" data-file-height="2368"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pyohunsa_Temple_-_Mount_Kumgang_North_Korea_(10449400303).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pyohunsa" title="Pyohunsa">Pyohunsa</a> Buddhist Temple, a <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="National Treasures of North Korea">National Treasure of North Korea</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite a historically strong Chinese influence, Korean culture has shaped its own unique identity.<sup id="cite_ref-Fairbank_et_al._396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fairbank_et_al.-396">[392]</a></sup> It came under attack during the <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japanese rule</a> from 1910 to 1945, when Japan enforced a <a href="/wiki/Cultural_assimilation" title="Cultural assimilation">cultural assimilation</a> policy. Koreans were forced to learn and speak Japanese, adopt the Japanese family name system and <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">Shinto</a> religion, and were forbidden to write or speak the Korean language in schools, businesses, or public places.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the peninsula was divided in 1945, two distinct cultures formed out of the common Korean heritage. North Koreans have little exposure to foreign influence.<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Culture_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Culture-398">[394]</a></sup> The revolutionary struggle and the brilliance of the leadership are some of the main themes in art. "Reactionary" elements from traditional culture have been discarded and cultural forms with a "folk" spirit have been reintroduced.<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Culture_398-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Culture-398">[394]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Korean heritage is protected and maintained by the state.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003496–497_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003496–497-399">[395]</a></sup> Over 190 historical sites and objects of national significance are cataloged as <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="National Treasures of North Korea">National Treasures of North Korea</a>, while some 1,800 less valuable artifacts are included in a list of <a href="/wiki/Cultural_assets_of_North_Korea" title="Cultural assets of North Korea">Cultural Assets</a>. The Historic Sites and Monuments in <a href="/wiki/Kaesong" title="Kaesong">Kaesong</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Complex_of_Goguryeo_Tombs" class="mw-redirect" title="Complex of Goguryeo Tombs">Complex of Goguryeo Tombs</a> are <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Korean_art" title="Korean art">Korean art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_architecture" title="Korean architecture">Korean architecture</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Visual arts are generally produced in the esthetics of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">Socialist realism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Socialist_realism_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Socialist_realism-401">[397]</a></sup> North Korean painting combines the influence of Soviet and Japanese visual expression to instill a sentimental loyalty to the system.<sup id="cite_ref-Art_world_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Art_world-402">[398]</a></sup> All artists in North Korea are required to join the Artists' Union, and the best among them can receive an official license to portray the leaders. Portraits and sculptures depicting Kim Il-sung, Kim Jong-il and Kim Jong-un are classed as "Number One works".<sup id="cite_ref-Socialist_realism_401-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Socialist_realism-401">[397]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most aspects of art have been dominated by <a href="/wiki/Mansudae_Art_Studio" title="Mansudae Art Studio">Mansudae Art Studio</a> since its establishment in 1959. It employs around 1,000 artists in what is likely the biggest art factory in the world where paintings, <a href="/wiki/Mural" title="Mural">murals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poster" title="Poster">posters</a> and monuments are designed and produced.<sup id="cite_ref-BussinessWeek_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BussinessWeek-403">[399]</a></sup> The studio has commercialized its activity and sells its works to collectors in a variety of countries including China, where it is in high demand.<sup id="cite_ref-Art_world_402-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Art_world-402">[398]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mansudae_Overseas_Projects" title="Mansudae Overseas Projects">Mansudae Overseas Projects</a> is a subdivision of Mansudae Art Studio that carries out construction of large-scale monuments for international customers.<sup id="cite_ref-BussinessWeek_403-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BussinessWeek-403">[399]</a></sup> Some of the projects include the <a href="/wiki/African_Renaissance_Monument" title="African Renaissance Monument">African Renaissance Monument</a> in <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Heroes%27_Acre_(Namibia)" title="Heroes' Acre (Namibia)">Heroes' Acre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Namibia" title="Namibia">Namibia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_Heritage">World Heritage</span></h3> 
      <p>In the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo_tombs" title="Goguryeo tombs">Goguryeo tumulus</a> is registered on the <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage">World Heritage</a> list of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>. These remains were registered as the first World Heritage property of North Korea in the UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Committee" title="World Heritage Committee">World Heritage Committee</a> (WHC) in July 2004. There are 63 burial mounds in the tomb group, with clear murals preserved. The burial customs of the Goguryeo culture have influenced Asian civilizations beyond Korea, including Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_North_Korea" title="Music of North Korea">Music of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <table role="presentation" class="mbox-small noprint" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;"> 
       <tbody>

         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div class="center">
           <div class="floatnone">
