        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" class="mbox-text" style="line-height:1.1em">
          <hr><i class="selfreference">Problems playing these files? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The government emphasized optimistic folk-based tunes and revolutionary music throughout most of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Culture_398-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Culture-398">[394]</a></sup> Ideological messages are conveyed through massive orchestral pieces like the "<a href="/wiki/Korean_revolutionary_opera" title="Korean revolutionary opera">Five Great Revolutionary Operas</a>" based on traditional Korean <i><a href="/wiki/Changgeuk" title="Changgeuk">ch'angguk</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Lit_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Lit-407">[403]</a></sup> Revolutionary operas differ from their Western counterparts by adding traditional instruments to the orchestra and avoiding <a href="/wiki/Recitative" title="Recitative">recitative</a> segments.<sup id="cite_ref-Sea_of_Blood_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sea_of_Blood-408">[404]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Blood" title="Sea of Blood">Sea of Blood</a></i> is the most widely performed of the Five Great Operas: since its premiere in 1971, it has been played over 1,500 times,<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[405]</a></sup> and its 2010 tour in China was a major success.<sup id="cite_ref-Sea_of_Blood_408-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sea_of_Blood-408">[404]</a></sup> Western <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a> by <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Brahms" title="Johannes Brahms">Brahms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Tchaikovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Stravinsky</a> and other composers is performed both by the <a href="/wiki/State_Symphony_Orchestra_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" title="State Symphony Orchestra of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">State Symphony Orchestra</a> and student orchestras.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[406]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">Pop music</a> appeared in the 1980s with the <a href="/wiki/Pochonbo_Electronic_Ensemble" title="Pochonbo Electronic Ensemble">Pochonbo Electronic Ensemble</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wangjaesan_Light_Music_Band" title="Wangjaesan Light Music Band">Wangjaesan Light Music Band</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Moranbong_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moranbong-411">[407]</a></sup> Improved relations with South Korea following the <a href="/wiki/2000_inter-Korean_summit" title="2000 inter-Korean summit">2000 inter-Korean summit</a> caused a decline in direct ideological messages in pop songs, but themes like comradeship, nostalgia and the construction of a powerful country remained.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003478_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003478-412">[408]</a></sup> In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/All-female_band" title="All-female band">all-girl</a> <a href="/wiki/Moranbong_Band" title="Moranbong Band">Moranbong Band</a> was described as the most popular group in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup> North Koreans also listen to <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a> which spreads through illegal markets.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_literature" title="North Korean literature">North Korean literature</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_(5015250703).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg/220px-North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg/330px-North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg/440px-North_Korea_%285015250703%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1280"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korea_(5015250703).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A North Korean bookstore with works of <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>All publishing houses are owned by the government or the WPK because they are considered an important tool for <a href="/wiki/Agitprop" title="Agitprop">propaganda and agitation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003423–424_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003423–424-416">[412]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea_Publishing_House" title="Workers' Party of Korea Publishing House">Workers' Party of Korea Publishing House</a> is the most authoritative among them and publishes all <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung_bibliography" title="Kim Il-sung bibliography">works of Kim Il-sung</a>, ideological education materials and party policy documents.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003424_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003424-417">[413]</a></sup> The availability of foreign literature is limited, examples being North Korean editions of Indian, German, Chinese and Russian fairy tales, <i><a href="/wiki/Tales_from_Shakespeare" title="Tales from Shakespeare">Tales from Shakespeare</a></i>, some works of <a href="/wiki/Bertolt_Brecht" title="Bertolt Brecht">Bertolt Brecht</a> and <a href="/wiki/Erich_K%C3%A4stner" title="Erich Kästner">Erich Kästner</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Art_world_402-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Art_world-402">[398]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_series" class="mw-redirect" title="Harry Potter series">Harry Potter series</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Kim Il-sung's personal works are considered "classical masterpieces" while the ones created under his instruction are labeled "models of <i>Juche</i> literature". These include <i>The Fate of a Self-Defense Corps Man</i>, <i>The Song of Korea</i> and <i>Immortal History</i>, a series of historical novels depicting the suffering of Koreans under Japanese occupation.<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Culture_398-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Culture-398">[394]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Lit_407-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Lit-407">[403]</a></sup> More than four million literary works were published between the 1980s and the early 2000s, but almost all of them belong to a narrow variety of political genres like "army-first revolutionary literature".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003475_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorth_Korea_Handbook2003475-419">[415]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">Science fiction</a> is considered a secondary genre because it somewhat departs from the traditional standards of detailed descriptions and metaphors of the leader. The exotic settings of the stories give authors more freedom to depict <a href="/wiki/Cyberwarfare" title="Cyberwarfare">cyberwarfare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Violence" title="Violence">violence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abuse" title="Sexual abuse">sexual abuse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime" title="Crime">crime</a>, which are absent in other genres. Sci-fi works glorify technology and promote the Juche concept of <a href="/wiki/Anthropocentrism" title="Anthropocentrism">anthropocentric existence</a> through depictions of <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">robotics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Immortality" title="Immortality">immortality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[416]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of North Korea">Media of North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG/220px-Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="297" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG/330px-Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG/440px-Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2544" data-file-height="3440"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pyongyang_TV_Tower_01.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pyongyang TV Tower
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Government policies towards <a href="/wiki/Film" title="Film">film</a> are no different than those applied to other arts—motion pictures serve to fulfill the targets of "social education". Some of the most influential films are based on historic events (<i>An Jung-geun shoots Itō Hirobumi</i>) or folk tales (<i><a href="/wiki/Hong_Gildong_jeon" title="Hong Gildong jeon">Hong Gildong</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-LCCS_Lit_407-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LCCS_Lit-407">[403]</a></sup> Most movies have predictable propaganda story lines which make cinema an unpopular entertainment; viewers only see films that feature their favorite actors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009114_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009114-421">[417]</a></sup> Western productions are only available at private showings to high-ranking Party members,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200994_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study200994-422">[418]</a></sup> although the 1997 film <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i> is frequently shown to university students as an example of Western culture.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[419]</a></sup> Access to foreign media products is available through smuggled <a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVDs</a> and television or radio broadcasts in border areas.<sup id="cite_ref-intermedia_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intermedia-424">[420]</a></sup> Western films like <i><a href="/wiki/The_Interview" title="The Interview">The Interview</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie%27s_Angels_(franchise)" title="Charlie's Angels (franchise)">Charlie's Angels</a></i> are just a few films that have been smuggled across the borders of North Korea, allowing for access to the North Korean citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[421]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[422]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korean media are under some of the strictest government control in the world. The <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_North_Korea" title="Censorship in North Korea">censorship in North Korea</a> encompasses all the information produced by the media. Monitored heavily by government officials, the media is strictly used to reinforce ideals approved by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-427">[423]</a></sup> There is no freedom of press in North Korea as all the media is controlled and filtered through governmental censors.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_427-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-427">[423]</a></sup> Freedom of the press in 2017 was 180th out of 180 countries in <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>' annual <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[424]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>, all media outlets serve as government mouthpieces, all journalists are party members and listening to foreign broadcasts carries the threat of a death penalty.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup> The main news provider is the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Central_News_Agency" title="Korean Central News Agency">Korean Central News Agency</a>. All 12 major <a href="/wiki/Newspapers_in_North_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Newspapers in North Korea">newspapers</a> and 20 periodicals, including <i><a href="/wiki/Rodong_Sinmun" title="Rodong Sinmun">Rodong Sinmun</a></i>, are published in the capital.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are three state-owned TV stations. Two of them broadcast only on weekends and the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Central_Television" title="Korean Central Television">Korean Central Television</a> is on air every day in the evenings.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Uriminzokkiri" title="Uriminzokkiri">Uriminzokkiri</a> and its associated <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">YouTube</a> and <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a> accounts distribute imagery, news and video issued by government media.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a> opened the first Western all-format, full-time bureau in Pyongyang in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Media_coverage_of_North_Korea" title="Media coverage of North Korea">Media coverage of North Korea</a> has often been inadequate as a result of the country's isolation. Stories like Kim Jong-un undergoing surgery to look like his grandfather, executing his ex-girlfriend or feeding his uncle to a pack of hungry dogs have been circulated by foreign media as truth despite the lack of a credible source.<sup id="cite_ref-transfixed_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transfixed-434">[430]</a></sup> Many of the claims originate from the South Korean <a href="/wiki/Right-wing" class="mw-redirect" title="Right-wing">right-wing</a> newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chosun_Ilbo" title="The Chosun Ilbo">The Chosun Ilbo</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup> Max Fisher of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> has written that "almost any story [on North Korea] is treated as broadly credible, no matter how outlandish or thinly sourced".<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[432]</a></sup> Occasional deliberate disinformation on the part of North Korean establishments further complicates the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-transfixed_434-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transfixed-434">[430]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_cuisine" title="North Korean cuisine">North Korean cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_(12330376074).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg/220px-North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg/330px-North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg/440px-North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_%2812330376074%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3568" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:North_Korean_Bibimbap_%EB%B9%84%EB%B9%94%EB%B0%A5_(12330376074).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korean <i><a href="/wiki/Bibimbap" title="Bibimbap">pibimbap</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Korean cuisine has evolved through centuries of social and political change. Originating from ancient <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Korea" title="Prehistoric Korea">agricultural and nomadic traditions</a> in southern <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, it has gone through a complex interaction of the natural environment and different cultural trends.<sup id="cite_ref-Korean_Cuisine_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Korean_Cuisine-437">[433]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">Rice</a> dishes and <a href="/wiki/Kimchi" title="Kimchi">kimchi</a> are staple Korean food. In a traditional meal, they accompany both side dishes (<i><a href="/wiki/Banchan" title="Banchan">panch'an</a></i>) and main courses like <i><a href="/wiki/Juk_(food)" class="mw-redirect" title="Juk (food)">juk</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bulgogi" title="Bulgogi">pulgogi</a></i> or <a href="/wiki/Noodles" class="mw-redirect" title="Noodles">noodles</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Soju" title="Soju">Soju</a></i> liquor is the best-known traditional Korean spirit.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[434]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea's most famous restaurant, <a href="/wiki/Okryu-gwan" title="Okryu-gwan">Okryu-gwan</a>, located in Pyongyang, is known for its <i><a href="/wiki/Naengmyeon" title="Naengmyeon">raengmyeon</a></i> cold noodles.<sup id="cite_ref-Okryu_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Okryu-439">[435]</a></sup> Other dishes served there include <a href="/wiki/Mullet_(fish)" title="Mullet (fish)">gray mullet</a> soup with boiled rice, <a href="/wiki/Galbitang" class="mw-redirect" title="Galbitang">beef rib soup</a>, green bean pancake, <i><a href="/wiki/Sinseollo" title="Sinseollo">sinsollo</a></i> and dishes made from <a href="/wiki/Diamondback_terrapin" title="Diamondback terrapin">terrapin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[436]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup> Okryu-gwan sends research teams into the countryside to collect data on <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">Korean cuisine</a> and introduce new recipes.<sup id="cite_ref-Okryu_439-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Okryu-439">[435]</a></sup> Some Asian cities host branches of the <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_(restaurant_chain)" title="Pyongyang (restaurant chain)">Pyongyang restaurant chain</a> where waitresses perform music and dance.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_North_Korea" title="Sport in North Korea">Sport in North Korea</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg/220px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg/330px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg/440px-FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3500" data-file-height="2387"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:FIFA_World_Cup_2010_Brazil_North_Korea_7.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>North Korea (in red) against Brazil at the 2010 FIFA World Cup
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_(7934639696).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg/220px-Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg/330px-Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg/440px-Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_%287934639696%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Laika_ac_Arirang_Mass_Games_(7934639696).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A scene from the 2012 <a href="/wiki/Arirang_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Arirang Festival">Arirang Festival</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Most schools have daily practice in <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gymnastics" title="Gymnastics">gymnastics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a> and others. The <a href="/wiki/DPR_Korea_League" class="mw-redirect" title="DPR Korea League">DPR Korea League</a> is popular inside the country and its games are often televised.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009114_421-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECountry_Study2009114-421">[417]</a></sup> The national football team, <i><a href="/wiki/Korea_DPR_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Korea DPR national football team">Chollima</a></i>, competed in the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> in <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010</a>, when it lost all three matches against <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team" title="Portugal national football team">Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast_national_football_team" title="Ivory Coast national football team">Ivory Coast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1966 FIFA World Cup">1966 appearance</a> was much more successful, seeing a surprise 1–0 victory over <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">Italy</a> and a quarter final loss to Portugal by 3–5.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[440]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="North Korea national basketball team">national team</a> represents the nation in international basketball competitions as well. In December 2013, former American basketball professional <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Rodman" title="Dennis Rodman">Dennis Rodman</a> visited North Korea to help train the national team after he developed a friendship with Kim Jong-un.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[441]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>North Korea's <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_Olympics" title="North Korea at the Olympics">first appearance</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Olympics">Olympics</a> came <a href="/wiki/1964_Winter_Olympics" title="1964 Winter Olympics">in 1964</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972 Olympics</a> saw its summer games debut and five medals, including one gold. With the exception of the boycotted <a href="/wiki/1984_Summer_Olympics" title="1984 Summer Olympics">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics" title="1988 Summer Olympics">Seoul Olympics</a>, North Korean athletes have won medals in all summer games since then.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[442]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Weightlifter" class="mw-redirect" title="Weightlifter">Weightlifter</a> <a href="/wiki/Kim_Un-guk" title="Kim Un-guk">Kim Un-guk</a> broke the <a href="/wiki/World_record" title="World record">world record</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Weightlifting_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_62_kg" title="Weightlifting at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's 62 kg">Men's 62 kg</a> category at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[443]</a></sup> Successful Olympians receive luxury apartments from the state in recognition for their achievements.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[444]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Arirang_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Arirang Festival">Arirang Festival</a> has been recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a> as the biggest choreographic event in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters2007_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters2007-449">[445]</a></sup> Some 100,000 athletes perform <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">rhythmic gymnastics</a> and dances while another 40,000 participants create a vast animated screen in the background. The event is an artistic representation of the country's history and pays homage to <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters2007_449-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters2007-449">[445]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-arirang_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arirang-450">[446]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rungrado_1st_of_May_Stadium" title="Rungrado 1st of May Stadium">Rungrado 1st of May Stadium</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_stadiums_by_capacity" title="List of stadiums by capacity">largest stadium in the world</a> with its capacity of 150,000, hosts the Festival.<sup id="cite_ref-arirang_450-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arirang-450">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[447]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang_Marathon" title="Pyongyang Marathon">Pyongyang Marathon</a> is another notable sports event. It is an <a href="/wiki/IAAF_Road_Race_Label_Events" class="mw-redirect" title="IAAF Road Race Label Events">IAAF Bronze Label Race</a> where amateur runners from around the world can participate.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[448]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 2010 and 2019, North Korea has imported 138 purebred horses from Russia at cost of over $584,000.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[449]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r992277484">.mw-parser-output .stack-container{box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .stack-clear-left{float:left;clear:left}.mw-parser-output .stack-clear-right{float:right;clear:right}.mw-parser-output .stack-left{float:left}.mw-parser-output .stack-right{float:right}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-clear-left{float:left;clear:left;margin-right:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-clear-right{float:right;clear:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-left{float:left;margin-right:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-right{float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-container>div{margin:1px;overflow:hidden}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .stack-container{float:none;width:100%}}</style>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-aaa-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-aaa_7-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kim Jong-un holds four concurrent positions: <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea">General Secretary of the Workers' Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_of_the_Workers%27_Party_of_Korea" title="Central Military Commission of the Workers' Party of Korea">Chairman of the Central Military Commission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_State_Affairs_Commission" title="Chairman of the State Affairs Commission">Chairman of the State Affairs Commission</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces</a>, serving as the "supreme leader" of the DPRK.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-bbb-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-bbb_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Choe Ryong-hae represents North Korea internationally. The Presidency was written out of the constitution in 1998. <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>, who died in 1994, was declared "<a href="/wiki/Eternal_leaders_of_North_Korea" title="Eternal leaders of North Korea">eternal President</a>" in its preamble.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ccc-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ccc_20-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Constitution of the DPRK. Article 1. The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is an independent socialist State representing the interests of all the Korean people.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ddd-169"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ddd_169-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In spite of the United States recognition of South Korea <i>de jure</i>, <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> acts as its <a href="/wiki/Protecting_power" title="Protecting power">protecting power</a>.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

         <li id="cite_note-:10-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:10_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:10_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/world/north-korea-defectors/">"Kim Jong Un's North Korea: Life inside the totalitarian state"</a>. <i>Washington Post</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Kim+Jong+Un%27s+North+Korea%3A+Life+inside+the+totalitarian+state&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fgraphics%2F2017%2Fworld%2Fnorth-korea-defectors%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-britannica-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-britannica_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-britannica_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/totalitarianism">"Totalitarianism"</a>. Encyclopædia Britannica. 2018.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Totalitarianism&amp;rft.pub=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Ftopic%2Ftotalitarianism&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-unstats08-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-unstats08_9-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-unstats08_9-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dyb2012/Table03.pdf#page=5"><i>Demographic Yearbook – Table 3: Population by sex, rate of population increase, surface area and density</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. United Nations Statistics Division. 2012. p.&nbsp;5<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 November</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Demographic+Yearbook+%E2%80%93+Table+3%3A+Population+by+sex%2C+rate+of+population+increase%2C+surface+area+and+density&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations+Statistics+Division&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Funstats.un.org%2Funsd%2Fdemographic%2Fproducts%2Fdyb%2Fdyb2012%2FTable03.pdf%23page%3D5&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSpencer2007" class="citation news cs1">Spencer, Richard (28 August 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/08/28/wnkorea128.xml">"North Korea power struggle looms"</a>. <i>The Telegraph (online version of United Kingdom's national newspaper)</i>. London. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071120121946/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F08%2F28%2Fwnkorea128.xml">Archived</a> from the original on 20 November 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>A power struggle to succeed Kim Jong-il as leader of North Korea's Stalinist dictatorship may be looming after his eldest son was reported to have returned from semi-voluntary exile.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Telegraph+%28online+version+of+United+Kingdom%27s+national+newspaper%29&amp;rft.atitle=North+Korea+power+struggle+looms&amp;rft.date=2007-08-28&amp;rft.aulast=Spencer&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.telegraph.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fmain.jhtml%3Fxml%3D%2Fnews%2F2007%2F08%2F28%2Fwnkorea128.xml&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFParry2007" class="citation news cs1"><a href="/wiki/Richard_Lloyd_Parry" title="Richard Lloyd Parry">Parry, Richard Lloyd</a> (5 September 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article2388356.ece">"North Korea's nuclear 'deal' leaves Japan feeling nervous"</a>. <i>The Times (online version of United Kingdom's national newspaper of record)</i>. London. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080726115520/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article2388356.ece">Archived</a> from the original on 26 July 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>The US Government contradicted earlier North Korean claims that it had agreed to remove the Stalinist dictatorship’s designation as a terrorist state and to lift economic sanctions, as part of talks aimed at disarming Pyongyang of its nuclear weapons.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Times+%28online+version+of+United+Kingdom%27s+national+newspaper+of+record%29&amp;rft.atitle=North+Korea%27s+nuclear+%27deal%27+leaves+Japan+feeling+nervous&amp;rft.date=2007-09-05&amp;rft.aulast=Parry&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+Lloyd&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.timesonline.co.uk%2Ftol%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Fasia%2Farticle2388356.ece&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWalsh2003" class="citation web cs1">Walsh, Lynn (8 February 2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071203224805/http://socialistworld.net/eng/2003/02/08korea.html">"The Korean crisis"</a>. <i>CWI online: Socialism Today, February 2003 edition, journal of the Socialist Party, CWI England and Wales</i>. socialistworld.net, website of the committee for a worker’s international. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://socialistworld.net/eng/2003/02/08korea.html">the original</a> on 3 December 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>Kim Jong-il's regime needs economic concessions to avoid collapse, and just as crucially needs an end to the strategic siege imposed by the U.S. since the end of the Korean war (1950–53). Pyongyang's nuclear <a href="/wiki/Brinkmanship" title="Brinkmanship">brinkmanship</a>, though potentially dangerous, is driven by fear rather than by militaristic ambition. The rotten Stalinist dictatorship faces the prospect of an implosion. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, which deprived North Korea of vital economic support, the nation has consistently attempted to secure from the US a non-aggression pact, recognition of its sovereignty, and economic assistance. The US's equally consistent refusal to enter into direct negotiations with North Korea, effectively ruling out a peace treaty to formally close the 1950–53 Korean War, has encouraged the regime to resort to nuclear blackmail.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=CWI+online%3A+Socialism+Today%2C+February+2003+edition%2C+journal+of+the+Socialist+Party%2C+CWI+England+and+Wales&amp;rft.atitle=The+Korean+crisis&amp;rft.date=2003-02-08&amp;rft.aulast=Walsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynn&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsocialistworld.net%2Feng%2F2003%2F02%2F08korea.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-nysuccess-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nysuccess_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBrooke2003" class="citation news cs1"><a href="/wiki/James_Brooke_(journalist)" title="James Brooke (journalist)">Brooke, James</a> (2 October 2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/02/international/asia/02CND-KORE.html?ex=1380513600&amp;en=a29d7f1e49aabee0&amp;ei=5007&amp;partner=USERLAND">"North Korea Says It Is Using Plutonium to Make A-Bombs"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071206032652/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/02/international/asia/02CND-KORE.html?ex=1380513600&amp;en=a29d7f1e49aabee0&amp;ei=5007&amp;partner=USERLAND">Archived</a> from the original on 6 December 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>North Korea, run by a Stalinist dictatorship for almost six decades, is largely closed to foreign reporters and it is impossible to independently check today's claims.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=North+Korea+Says+It+Is+Using+Plutonium+to+Make+A-Bombs&amp;rft.date=2003-10-02&amp;rft.aulast=Brooke&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2003%2F10%2F02%2Finternational%2Fasia%2F02CND-KORE.html%3Fex%3D1380513600%26en%3Da29d7f1e49aabee0%26ei%3D5007%26partner%3DUSERLAND&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11465278">"A portrait of North Korea's new rich"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>. 29 May 2008. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080802001701/http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11465278">Archived</a> from the original on 2 August 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 June</span> 2009</span>. <q>EVERY developing country worth its salt has a bustling middle class that is transforming the country and thrilling the markets.          <li id="cite_note-Lankov1945-1948-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lankov1945-1948_53-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLankov" class="citation book cs1">Lankov, Andrei. "<span class="cs1-kern-left">"</span>North Korea in 1945–48: The Soviet Occupation and the Birth of the State,<span class="cs1-kern-right">"</span>". <i>From Stalin to Kim Il Sung – The Formation of North Korea, 1945–1960</i>. pp.&nbsp;2–3.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=%22North+Korea+in+1945%E2%80%9348%3A+The+Soviet+Occupation+and+the+Birth+of+the+State%2C%22&amp;rft.btitle=From+Stalin+to+Kim+Il+Sung+%E2%80%93+The+Formation+of+North+Korea%2C+1945%E2%80%931960&amp;rft.pages=2-3&amp;rft.aulast=Lankov&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrei&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Lankov2-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lankov2_54-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLankov2013" class="citation book cs1">Lankov, Andrei (10 April 2013). <i>The Real North Korea: Life and Politics in the Failed Stalinist Utopia</i>. Oxford University Press. p.&nbsp;7.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Real+North+Korea%3A+Life+and+Politics+in+the+Failed+Stalinist+Utopia&amp;rft.pages=7&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013-04-10&amp;rft.aulast=Lankov&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrei&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090627213353/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C528320%2C00.html">"U.S.: N. Korea Boosting Guerrilla War Capabilities"</a>. FOX News Network, LLC. Associated Press. 23 June 2009. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,528320,00.html">the original</a> on 27 June 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">4 July</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=U.S.%3A+N.+Korea+Boosting+Guerrilla+War+Capabilities&amp;rft.date=2009-06-23&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.foxnews.com%2Fstory%2F0%2C2933%2C528320%2C00.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Kim_p.45-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kim_p.45_56-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKim2014" class="citation book cs1">Kim, Samuel S. (2014). "The Evolving Asian System". <i>International Relations of Asia</i>. <a href="/wiki/Rowman_%26_Littlefield" title="Rowman &amp; Littlefield">Rowman &amp; Littlefield</a>. p.&nbsp;45. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1442226418" title="Special:BookSources/978-1442226418"><bdi>978-1442226418</bdi></a>. <q>With three of the four major Cold War fault lines—divided Germany, divided Korea, divided China, and divided Vietnam—East Asia acquired the dubious distinction of having engendered the largest number of armed conflicts resulting in higher fatalities between 1945 and 1994 than any other region or sub-region. Even in Asia, while Central and South Asia produced a regional total of 2.8 million in human fatalities, East Asia's regional total is 10.4 million including the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> (1 million), the Korean War (3 million), the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> (2 million), and the <a href="/wiki/Pol_Pot" title="Pol Pot">Pol Pot</a> <a href="/wiki/Cambodian_genocide" title="Cambodian genocide">genocide</a> in Cambodia (1 to 2 million).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Evolving+Asian+System&amp;rft.btitle=International+Relations+of+Asia&amp;rft.pages=45&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1442226418&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Samuel+S.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Cumings_p._35-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cumings_p._35_57-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCumings2011" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Bruce_Cumings" title="Bruce Cumings">Cumings, Bruce</a> (2011). <i>The Korean War: A History</i>. <a href="/wiki/Modern_Library" title="Modern Library">Modern Library</a>. p.&nbsp;35. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0812978964" title="Special:BookSources/978-0812978964"><bdi>978-0812978964</bdi></a>. <q>Various encyclopedias state that the countries involved in the three-year conflict suffered a total of more than 4 million casualties, of which at least 2 million were civilians—a higher percentage than in World War II or Vietnam. A total of 36,940 Americans lost their lives in the Korean theater; of these, 33,665 were killed in action, while 3,275 died there of nonhostile causes. Some 92,134 Americans were wounded in action, and decades later, 8,176 were still reported as missing. South Korea sustained 1,312,836 casualties, including 415,004 dead. Casualties among other UN allies totaled 16,532, including 3,094 dead. Estimated North Korean casualties numbered 2 million, including about one million civilians and 520,000 soldiers. An estimated 900,000 Chinese soldiers lost their lives in combat.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Korean+War%3A+A+History&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Modern+Library&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0812978964&amp;rft.aulast=Cumings&amp;rft.aufirst=Bruce&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMcGuire2010" class="citation book cs1">McGuire, James (2010). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/wealthhealthdemo00mcgu"><i>Wealth, Health, and Democracy in East Asia and Latin America</i></a></span>. <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>. p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/wealthhealthdemo00mcgu/page/n217">203</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1139486224" title="Special:BookSources/978-1139486224"><bdi>978-1139486224</bdi></a>. <q>In Korea, war in the early 1950s cost nearly 3 million lives, including nearly a million civilian dead in South Korea.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Wealth%2C+Health%2C+and+Democracy+in+East+Asia+and+Latin+America&amp;rft.pages=203&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-1139486224&amp;rft.aulast=McGuire&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fwealthhealthdemo00mcgu&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPainter1999" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/David_S._Painter" title="David S. Painter">Painter, David S.</a> (1999). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/coldwarinternati00pain"><i>The Cold War: An International History</i></a></span>. <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a>. p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/coldwarinternati00pain/page/n40">30</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0415153164" title="Special:BookSources/978-0415153164"><bdi>978-0415153164</bdi></a>. <q>Before it ended, the Korean War cost over 3 million people their lives, including over 50,000 US servicemen and women and a much higher number of Chinese and Korean lives. The war also set in motion a number of changes that led to the militarization and intensification of the Cold War.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cold+War%3A+An+International+History&amp;rft.pages=30&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=978-0415153164&amp;rft.aulast=Painter&amp;rft.aufirst=David+S.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fcoldwarinternati00pain&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Lewy_pp._450-453-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lewy_pp._450-453_60-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLewy1980" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Guenter_Lewy" title="Guenter Lewy">Lewy, Guenter</a> (1980). <a href="/wiki/America_in_Vietnam" title="America in Vietnam"><i>America in Vietnam</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp.&nbsp;450–453. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0199874231" title="Special:BookSources/978-0199874231"><bdi>978-0199874231</bdi></a>. <q>For the Korean War the only hard statistic is that of American military deaths, which included 33,629 battle deaths and 20,617 who died of other causes. The North Korean and Chinese Communists never published statistics of their casualties. The number of South Korean military deaths has been given as in excess of 400,000; the South Korean Ministry of Defense puts the number of killed and missing at 281,257. Estimates of communist troops killed are about one-half million. The total number of Korean civilians who died in the fighting, which left almost every major city in North and South Korea in ruins, has been estimated at between 2 and 3 million. This adds up to almost 1 million military deaths and a possible 2.5 million civilians who were killed or died as a result of this extremely destructive conflict. The proportion of civilians killed in the major wars of this century (and not only in the major ones) has thus risen steadily. It reached about 42 percent in World War II and may have gone as high as 70 percent in the Korean War.&nbsp;... we find that the ratio of civilian to military deaths [in Vietnam] is not substantially different from that of World War II and is well below that of the Korean War.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=America+in+Vietnam&amp;rft.pages=450-453&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.isbn=978-0199874231&amp;rft.aulast=Lewy&amp;rft.aufirst=Guenter&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFArmstrong2010" class="citation journal cs1">Armstrong, Charles K. (20 December 2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://apjjf.org/-Charles-K--Armstrong/3460/article.pdf">"The Destruction and Reconstruction of North Korea, 1950–1960"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The Asia-Pacific Journal</i>. <b>8</b> (51): 1<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 September</span> 2019</span>. <q>The number of Korean dead, injured or missing by war's end approached three million, ten percent of the overall population. The majority of those killed were in the North, which had half of the population of the South; although the DPRK does not have official figures, possibly twelve to fifteen percent of the population was killed in the war, a figure close to or surpassing the proportion of Soviet citizens killed in World War II.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Asia-Pacific+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Destruction+and+Reconstruction+of+North+Korea%2C+1950%E2%80%931960&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=51&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.date=2010-12-20&amp;rft.aulast=Armstrong&amp;rft.aufirst=Charles+K.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapjjf.org%2F-Charles-K--Armstrong%2F3460%2Farticle.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCumings1997" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Bruce_Cumings" title="Bruce Cumings">Cumings, Bruce</a> (1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/koreasplaceinsun00bruc/page/297"><i>Korea's Place in the Sun: A Modern History</i></a>. WW Norton &amp; Company. pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/koreasplaceinsun00bruc/page/297">297–298</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-393-31681-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-393-31681-0"><bdi>978-0-393-31681-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korea%27s+Place+in+the+Sun%3A+A+Modern+History&amp;rft.pages=297-298&amp;rft.pub=WW+Norton+%26+Company&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-393-31681-0&amp;rft.aulast=Cumings&amp;rft.aufirst=Bruce&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fkoreasplaceinsun00bruc%2Fpage%2F297&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJager2013" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Sheila_Miyoshi_Jager" title="Sheila Miyoshi Jager">Jager, Sheila Miyoshi</a> (2013). <i>Brothers at War – The Unending Conflict in Korea</i>. London: Profile Books. pp.&nbsp;237–242. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84668-067-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84668-067-0"><bdi>978-1-84668-067-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Brothers+at+War+%E2%80%93+The+Unending+Conflict+in+Korea&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=237-242&amp;rft.pub=Profile+Books&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84668-067-0&amp;rft.aulast=Jager&amp;rft.aufirst=Sheila+Miyoshi&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-AMH-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-AMH_64-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRichard_W._Stewart2005" class="citation book cs1">Richard W. Stewart, ed. (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.history.army.mil/books/AMH-V2/AMH%20V2/chapter8.htm">"The Korean War, 1950–1953"</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.history.army.mil/books/AMH-V2/AMH%20V2/"><i>American Military History, Volume 2</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Center_of_Military_History" title="United States Army Center of Military History">United States Army Center of Military History</a>. CMH Pub 30-22. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080528231553/http://www.history.army.mil/books/AMH-V2/AMH%20V2/">Archived</a> from the original on 28 May 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 August</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Korean+War%2C+1950%E2%80%931953&amp;rft.btitle=American+Military+History%2C+Volume+2&amp;rft.pub=United+States+Army+Center+of+Military+History&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.history.army.mil%2Fbooks%2FAMH-V2%2FAMH%2520V2%2Fchapter8.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbt,_Felix2014" class="citation book cs1">Abt, Felix (2014). <i>A Capitalist in North Korea: My Seven Years in the Hermit Kingdom</i>. Tuttle Publishing. pp.&nbsp;125–126. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804844390" title="Special:BookSources/9780804844390"><bdi>9780804844390</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Capitalist+in+North+Korea%3A+My+Seven+Years+in+the+Hermit+Kingdom&amp;rft.pages=125-126&amp;rft.pub=Tuttle+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=9780804844390&amp;rft.au=Abt%2C+Felix&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Brune1996-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Brune1996_66-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLester_H._Brune1996" class="citation book cs1">Lester H. Brune (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tq5JIGX04bgC&amp;pg=PA60"><i>The Korean War: Handbook of the Literature and Research</i></a>. Greenwood Publishing Group. p.&nbsp;60. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-28969-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-28969-9"><bdi>978-0-313-28969-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Korean+War%3A+Handbook+of+the+Literature+and+Research&amp;rft.pages=60&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-28969-9&amp;rft.au=Lester+H.+Brune&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dtq5JIGX04bgC%26pg%3DPA60&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-67">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kirkbride, Wayne (1984). <i>DMZ, a story of the Panmunjom axe murder</i>. Hollym International Corp.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-68">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBandowCarpenter1992" class="citation book cs1">Bandow, Doug; Carpenter, Ted Galen, eds. (1992). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HXdhDRCGD1kC&amp;pg=PA99"><i>The U.S.-South Korean Alliance: Time for a Change</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_104-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGranthamDuncanEvansJones2020" class="citation journal cs1">Grantham, H. S.; et&nbsp;al.          <li id="cite_note-hitchens07-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-hitchens07_116-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHitchens2007" class="citation news cs1">Hitchens, Christopher (24 December 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.slate.com/id/2180464/">"Why has the Bush administration lost interest in North Korea?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Slate_(magazine)" title="Slate (magazine)">Slate</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100520172644/http://www.slate.com/id/2180464/">Archived</a> from the original on 20 May 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAndrei_Lankov2009" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Andrei_Lankov" title="Andrei Lankov">Andrei Lankov</a> (4 December 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100104035159/http://feer.com/reviews/2009/december51/the-cleanest-race-how-north-koreans-see-themselves-and-why-it-matters">"Review of <i>The Cleanest Race</i>"</a>. <i>Far Eastern Economic Review</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://feer.com/reviews/2009/december51/the-cleanest-race-how-north-koreans-see-themselves-and-why-it-matters">the original</a> on 4 January 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 June</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Far+Eastern+Economic+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Review+of+The+Cleanest+Race&amp;rft.date=2009-12-04&amp;rft.au=Andrei+Lankov&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ffeer.com%2Freviews%2F2009%2Fdecember51%2Fthe-cleanest-race-how-north-koreans-see-themselves-and-why-it-matters&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Christopher_Hitchens" title="Christopher Hitchens">Christopher Hitchens</a>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2010/02/a_nation_of_racist_dwarfs.html">A Nation of Racist Dwarfs – Kim Jong-il's regime is even weirder and more despicable than you thought</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120601044431/http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/2010/02/a_nation_of_racist_dwarfs.html">Archived</a> 1 June 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> (2010)</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBrian_Reynolds_Myers2009" class="citation news cs1"><a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Brian Reynolds Myers</a> (1 October 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704471504574445980801810944">"The Constitution of Kim Jong Il"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal" class="mw-redirect" title="Wall Street Journal">Wall Street Journal</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121110074510/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704471504574445980801810944.html">Archived</a> from the original on 10 November 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 December</span> 2012</span>. <q>From its beginnings in 1945 the regime has espoused—to its subjects if not to its Soviet and Chinese aid-providers—a race-based, paranoid nationalism that has nothing to do with Marxism-Leninism. [...] North Korea has always had less in common with the former Soviet Union than with the Japan of the 1930s, another 'national defense state' in which a command economy was pursued not as an end in itself, but as a prerequisite for rapid armament. North Korea is, in other words, a national-socialist country</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Constitution+of+Kim+Jong+Il.&amp;rft.date=2009-10-01&amp;rft.au=Brian+Reynolds+Myers&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wsj.com%2Farticles%2FSB10001424052748704471504574445980801810944&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/08/13/2013081301558.html">The Twisted Logic of the N.Korean Regime</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170113064929/http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/08/13/2013081301558.html">Archived</a> 13 January 2017 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>. Chosun Ilbo. 13 August 2013. Accessed date: 11 January 2017.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-144">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFStaff2013" class="citation web cs1">Staff (27 December 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140126131556/http://newfocusintl.com/just-witnessed-coup-north-korea/">"We have just witnessed a coup in North Korea"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-162">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19910917&amp;slug=1306025">"A Single Flag – North And South Korea Join U.N.          <li id="cite_note-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-277">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2020.pdf">UN HDR 2020 PDF</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases-278"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Overview_of_the_Burden_of_Diseases_278-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLeeYoonKimYeom2013" class="citation journal cs1">Lee, Yo Han; Yoon, Seok-Jun; Kim, Young Ae; Yeom, Ji Won; Oh, In-Hwan (1 May 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3677063">"Overview of the Burden of Diseases in North Korea"</a>. <i>Journal of Preventive Medicine and Public Health</i>. <b>46</b> (3): 111–117. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.3961%2Fjpmph.2013.46.3.111">10.3961/jpmph.2013.46.3.111</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&nbsp;<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3677063">3677063</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23766868">23766868</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Preventive+Medicine+and+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Overview+of+the+Burden+of+Diseases+in+North+Korea&amp;rft.volume=46&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=111-117&amp;rft.date=2013-05-01&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3677063%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F23766868&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.3961%2Fjpmph.2013.46.3.111&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Yo+Han&amp;rft.au=Yoon%2C+Seok-Jun&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Young+Ae&amp;rft.au=Yeom%2C+Ji+Won&amp;rft.au=Oh%2C+In-Hwan&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3677063&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Language-296"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Language_296-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Language_296-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Cavendish2007-298"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cavendish2007_298-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=YG2AFyFppJQC&amp;pg=PA933"><i>World and Its Peoples: Eastern and Southern Asia</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Cavendish" title="Marshall Cavendish">Marshall Cavendish</a>. 2007. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780761476313" title="Special:BookSources/9780761476313"><bdi>9780761476313</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-PalmerOBrien1993-299"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PalmerOBrien1993_299-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJoanne_O'Brien,_Martin_Palmer1993" class="citation book cs1">Joanne O'Brien, Martin Palmer (December 1993). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/stateofreligiona00obri"><i>The State of Religion Atlas</i></a></span>. <a href="/wiki/Simon_%26_Schuster" title="Simon &amp; Schuster">Simon &amp; Schuster</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 May</span> 2019</span>. <q>Atheism continues to be the official position of the governments of China, North Korea and Cuba.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+State+of+Religion+Atlas&amp;rft.pub=Simon+%26+Schuster&amp;rft.date=1993-12&amp;rft.au=Joanne+O%27Brien%2C+Martin+Palmer&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fstateofreligiona00obri&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANorth+Korea" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-300"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-300">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-HRNKSongbun-309"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HRNKSongbun_309-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-NKSongbun-310"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-NKSongbun_310-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NKSongbun_310-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMatthew_McGrath2012" class="citation news cs1">Matthew McGrath (7 June 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nknews.org/2012/06/marked-for-life-songbun-north-koreas-social-classification-system/">"Marked for Life: Songbun, North Korea's Social Classification System"</a>. <i>NK News</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130318004158/http://www.nknews.org/2012/06/marked-for-life-songbun-north-koreas-social-classification-system/">Archived</a> from the original on 18 March 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">.
